{{Infobox musical artist | honorific_prefix = | name = '''Ilhama Guliyeva''' | honorific_suffix = {{lang-az|İlhamə Quliyeva}} | image = [[File:Ilhama Guliyeva.jpg|frameless|center]] | image_upright = | image_size = | landscape = | alt = | caption = | background = solo_singer | native_name = İlhamə Məzahir qızı Quliyeva | native_name_lang = İlhamə Quliyeva | birth_name = | alias = "Primadonna", "The Art Queen of the Turkic World" | birth_date = 17 August 1943 | birth_place = [[File:Flag of Azerbaijan SSR.svg|border|24px|Flag of Azerbaijan SSR]] [[Azerbaijani SSR]]
{{USSR}} | origin = [[Lankaran]], {{AZE}} | death_date = 25 February 2016 (72 years) | death_place = [[Baku]], [[Azerbaijan]] | genre = [[Azerbaijani folk music]], [[mugham]], [[art music]], [[classical music|classical]] | occupation = singer, actress | instrument = | years_active = 1965–2016 | label = | associated_acts = #[[:az:Tükəzban İsmayılova|Tükəzban İsmayılova]] #[[:az:Həbib Bayramov|Həbib Bayramov]] #[[Tofig Guliyev]] #[[Khayyam Mirzazade]] #[[Fikrat Amirov]] #[[:az:Oqtay Kazımi|Oqtay Kazımi]] #[[:az:Ramiz Mirişli|Ramiz Mirişli]] #[[:az:Oqtay Rəcəbov|Oqtay Rəcəbov]] #[[:az:Elza Ibrahimova|Elza Ibrahimova]] #[[Emin Sabitoglu]] #[[:az:Faiq Sücəddinov|Faiq Sücəddinov]] | website = | module = }} {{Infobox person | name = Honours and Awards | awards = #[[Honored Artist]] of [[Azerbaijani SSR]] (1982) #[[People's Artist]] of the [[Republic of Azerbaijan]] (1998) #[[File:Şöhrət ordeni (Azərbaycan)-lent.svg|right|55px]] [[Shohrat Order]] (2002) #[[People's Artist]] of the [[Republic of Dagestan]] (2007) #[[Goodwill Ambassador]] (2007) #[[File:AZ Sharaf Order ribbon.png|right|60px]] [[Sharaf Order]] (2013) | image = [[File:Şöhrət ordeni (Azərbaycan).png|30px|left]] [[File:“Əməkdar artist” fəxri adının döş nişanı.jpg|68px|middle|bottom]] [[File:“Xalq artisti” fəxri adının döş nişanı.jpg|68px|middle|bottom]] [[File:Şərəf ordeni (boyundan asmaq üçün).png|65px|right]] }} '''Ilhama Guliyeva''' (17 August 1943, [[Lankaran]], [[Azerbaijani SSR]] — 25 February 2016, [[Baku]], [[Azerbaijan]]) was an [[Azerbaijani people|Azerbaijani]] [[celebrity]], [[actress]] and [[singer]] of Azerbaijani [[folk music|folk]] and [[classical music]]. Throughout active musical-stage career, Ilhama Guliyeva gained popular success in her respective genre of music and received such major state-level honors as [[Honored Artist]] of [[Azerbaijani SSR]] in 1982, [[People's Artist]] of the [[Republic of Azerbaijan]] in 1998 and People's Artist of the [[Republic of Dagestan]] in 2007. == Biography == === Early life === Ilhama Guliyeva was born on August 17, 1943 in [[Lankaran]], [[Azerbaijani SSR]]. Her mother – {{ill|Tükəzban İsmayılova|az}}, was a popular [[Azerbaijani people|Azerbaijani]] singer and [[khanende]], and father – Mazahir Guliyev, worked as a [[prosecutor]] in Lankaran. Due to his job appointment, Ilhama Guliyeva spent her very early years in [[Shaki, Azerbaijan|Shaki]] city of Azerbaijan. However, when Ilhama reaches the age of six, her parents divorce. Ilhama Guliyeva's mother, moving to [[Baku]], marries a famous Azerbaijani [[taar|tar]] player – {{ill|Həbib Bayramov|az}}, who later becomes a supportive [[stepfather]] that actively engages in growing up and educating Ilhama Guliyeva. === Education === At this early age, she gets enrolled in a 7-year musical school for piano training in [[Baku]]. As Guliyeva finishes both musical and high schools, with a great desire she wants to build her profession in the musical field. Nevertheless, young Ilhama faces definitive dissent from her parents. Taking into account the difficulties of music, they try to inspire her to master another art. Therefore, she enters the faculty of [[philology]] of the [[Azerbaijan State University]] in 1960 and continues non-musical studies in subsequent years. In 1964, Ilhama Guliyeva graduates from the university, but like every talented person with high [[musical intelligence]], young Guliyeva could not get away from music. === Early musical career === In 1963, with the support of Ziniat Alizadeh, who was in close relations with Guliyeva's family, she starts performing at the university's "''Sevinj''" [[pop music|pop]] ensemble. As Guliyeva's parents still oppressed her passion for music, these musical activities were kept in secret from her family. In 1964, a competition of young talents from all over the world was held in [[Moscow]]. By the request of Mrs. Zinyat, Ilhama Guliyeva gets permission from her family and flies to [[Russia]]. Her family thought she was going to the festival as a [[Audience|spectator]]. Competing with young singers from many countries, Ilhama Guliyeva performs the songs of [[Rauf Hajiyev]] and [[Tofig Guliyev]]. As Guliyeva becomes the winner of the competition, she returns to Baku and gets invited to perform at the [[orchestra]] of the Azerbaijan State Television and Radio Broadcasting Company ([[AzTV]]). Starting from 1965 until 1970, Ilhama Gulliyeva starts performing songs composed by [[Khayyam Mirzazade]], [[Tofig Bakikhanov]] and [[Emin Sabitoglu]] in various genres of [[pop music]], such as [[slow rock]], [[jazz]], [[R & B]], [[soul music|soul]] and [[blues]], as a [[solo (music)|soloist]] of the orchestra, headed by {{ill|Tofiq Əhmədov|az}}. === 1970s – 1980s === From 1970 until 1980, Ilhama Guliyeva performed at various stages as a soloist of the [[Azerbaijan State Philharmonic Hall]]. In 1972, "''The Evening of Azerbaijani Composers''" gets held in the [[House of the Unions]] in [[Moscow]] where Guliyeva performs several songs. After the concert, a promimnent Azerbaijani composer [[Fikrat Amirov]] meets with Guliyeva and promises to compose [[art songs]] for her. Such songs as "''Mən səni araram''", "''Göy Göl''", "''Gülür ellər gülür''", "''Gülərəm gülsən''", "''Toy mahnısı/Toydur bugün''" and "''De görüm neyləmişəm''" became wonderful musical outputs of their cooperation, which went down in history of [[Azerbaijani music]] since then. Each of these songs is accompanied by [[folk instruments]] and [[orchestra]], and has its own unique and colorful shades peculiar to [[Azerbaijani folk music]]. In the late 1970s, accompanied by the [[instrumental ensemble|Musical ensemble]] "Dan Ulduzu", which was headed by Gulala Aliyeva, Ilhama Guliyeva performs many art songs of such outstanding Azerbaijani composers as {{ill|Oqtay Kazımi|az}}, {{ill|Oqtay Rəcəbov|az}}, {{ill|Ramiz Mirişli|az}}, [[Arif Malikov]], [[Ahmad Bakikhanov]] etc. Since then, Ilhama Guliyeva goes on tours to foreign countries ([[England]], [[Spain]], [[Denmark]], [[Turkey]], [[Germany]] etc.) and represents Azerbaijani music on the world stage. === 1990s – 2000s === After the death of {{ill|Habib Bayramov|az}} in 1994, {{ill|Tükazban İsmayılova|az}} stopped performing and quit the musical stage. This heavily affects Ilhama Guliyeva, and she quits singing for a short period of time. After several years, Guliyeva starts to cooperate with an Azerbaijani composer {{ill|Faiq Sücəddinov|az}} and performs such popular in Azerbaijan lyrical songs as "''Neylərsən''", "''Kaman''", "''Bilsən necə darıxmışam''" etc. In the beginning of the first decade of the 2000s, Guliyeva performed such songs as "''Gedirəm''", "''Unut Məni''", "''Unuda bilməzsən''" and "'''Yaşın nə fərqi var ki?/Love knows no age'''" which became appellative and the most popular song of Guliyeva's repertoire. This and other series of lyrical songs of Guliyeva contributed to transformation of [[Azerbaijani music]]. Since the beginning of the second decade of the 2000s, Guliyeva became the venerable elderly artist in the field of music in Azerbaijan, and young artists began making [[cover version]]s of art songs that she used to sing. === Socio-political activity === In the beginning of the 2000s, Ilhama Guliyeva publicly supports a new candidate for presidency – [[Ilham Aliyev]]. She gives concerts in the regions of Azerbaijan, runs her [[propaganda]] and makes a worthy contribution to Ilham Aliyev's successful election. Moreover, in 2002, Guliyeva receives the status of "''International Cultural Executor''" at the World Women's Congress[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Women%27s_International_Democratic_Federation Women's International Democratic Federation (WIDF)] in [[Beirut]], the title of "''The Art Queen of the Turkic World''" in [[country|Turkey]] and four Humay Awards in Azerbaijan.[http://kaspi.az/az/az/ilhame-quliyevanin-mehebbet-dusturu/ İlhamə Quliyevanın məhəbbət düsturu] Since 2003, together with a group of intelligent Azerbaijani women, Ilhama Guliyeva participated in several [[United Nations Office at Geneva|UN Geneva]] meetings and defended the rights of Azerbaijani women and children who had been affected by the [[Nagorno-Karabakh conflict]]. In 2004, at various conferences, symposiums and protest rallies in [[Goteborg]], [[Strasbourg]], [[Paris]], [[Istanbul]] and in front of the building of [[European Parliament]] in [[Brussels]], Guliyeva had comprehensive public speeches on [[Armenian-controlled territories surrounding Nagorno-Karabakh|Armenian occupation]] of Azerbaijani internationally recognized territories. As the result of active socio-political participation, Guliyeva was elected as the president of the "''Academy of Culture''" under the World Congress of Azerbaijanis/[[:az:Dünya Azərbaycanlıları Konqresi|Dünya Azərbaycanlıları Konqresi]] in 2004. In 2007, at the headquarters of the [[Universal Peace Federation]] in [[Washington DC]], Guliyeva received the status of [[Goodwill Ambassador]]. [[File:Ilhama Guliyeva 2011.jpg|thumb|left|Ilhama Guliyeva receives "''Yaxşıların Yaxşısı'' / Best of the Bests" Award, 2011.]] == Personal life == Ilhama Guliyeva created a short-term family life with '''Faig Mirmohsunov''' in the 1980s. During this very short marriage period, she adopted the surname of her spouse. However, she ended this marriage shortly and returned to her original last name. Moreover, Guliyeva adobted a child – '''Orkhan Nadirov''', who is claimed to be a grandson of Guliyeva's aunt. == Guliyeva and contradictory attitudes towards her personality == [[File:Ilhama Guliyeva at the TV Show-Program.jpg|thumb|right|Ilhama Guliyeva at the TV Show "A-dan Z-yə". [[ANS TV]] studio, 2015.]] Ilhama Guliyeva was a very peculiar [[musical artist]] with flamboyant personality. Despite that Guliyeva was respected and loved for her voice and songs, she constantly faced public criticism and dissent towards her personality. Considering the fact that the major segment of Azerbaijani society is [[conservative]] with [[traditional values]], this persistent negative attitude towards Guliyeva was due to her liberal behavior with regard to love affairs in the 1980s and 90s. However, nowadays it is an interesting scene to observe when foreign musical artists with no greater decent "ethical" background visit Azerbaijan, the people rush to highly greet and express their deep respect towards them in concert halls and [[social media]]. Considering these vestiges as a temporary phenomenon of a developing society, she never took them seriously, continued to actively participate in musical life of the country and became a leading musical artist of so-called [[show business]] in Azerbaijan. ===Ilhama Guliyeva vs. Flora Kerimova=== Guliyeva was [[hegemonic]], loved glory and honor, as well as demanded respectful attitude from everyone. This made her get into numerous conflicts with many other musical artists of Azerbaijan. Her major disputes were with such Azerbaijani singers as [[:az:Nazpəri Dostəliyeva|Nazpəri Dostəliyeva]], [[:az:Elza Seyidcahan|Elza Seyidcahan]], [[Aygün Kazımova]] and [[Brilliant Dadashova]]. Although she had a good and friendly relationship with all her colleagues at the end of her life, the only artist with whom she had not put up since the beginning of her musical career was another [[People's Artist]] of [[Azerbaijan]] [[Flora Kerimova]]. Despite that in 1995, during the joint interview with Kerimova and Guliyeva, they claimed not to be rivals since the genres of music they performed were different, it is not a secret that the issues as "who would go on stage to perform first" or "who would record a song of popular composer before anyone else" were ones of the main causes of their enmity. Since Kerimova went on streets against newly elected Azerbaijani government in 2003, she became unwelcomed and later left her active musical career. However, as [[TV channel]]s were inviting Kerimova to [[talk shows]], she used to insult Guliyeva, naming her a "disgrace to the musical stage and art, as well as to the Azerbaijani nation".[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sfHr4E3u26I İlhamə Quliyeva səhnəyə, sənətə və millətə ləkədir] Yet, while Guliyeva in her public and TV speeches held Kerimova in high esteem,[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-7ZYBIalM6M İlhamə Quliyeva Flora Kərimova haqda danışdı] Kerimova's attitude towards Guliyeva didn't change throughout time. [[File:Ilhama Guliyeva and Zeynab Khanlarova.jpg|thumb|left|Ilhama Guliyeva (left) and [[Zeynab Khanlarova]] (right) at the [[Heydar Aliyev Center]], Baku, 2015.]] == Unexpected death == Starting from 2016, Ilhama Guliyeva had [[heart failure]] simptoms. Having full of vigour and enthusiasm, Ilhama Guliyeva died of [[thromboembolism]] on February 25, 2016. Despite the fact that [[ambulance service]] arrived on time, her health condition had already deteriorated.[http://news.milli.az/culture/410773.html İlhamə Quliyeva vəfat etdi] On February 26, 2016, Ilhama Guliyeva was buried next to her mother {{ill|Tükazban Ismayılova|az}} and stepfather {{ill|Həbib Bayramov|az}} in the Second [[Alley of Honor]] in [[Baku]]. The reason of the death of Ilhama Guliyeva was investigated and revealed by ''the Court of Medical Expertise and Pathological Anatomy'' of [[Azerbaijan]]. As a sign of respect towards Guliyeva's musical creativity, such Azerbaijani high ranking social and political figures as President [[Ilham Aliyev]], Prime Minister [[Artur Rasizade]], Speaker of National Assembly [[Ogtay Asadov]], Minister of Culture and Tourism [[Abulfaz Garayev]], [[People's Artist of USSR]] and [[Azerbaijan]] [[Zeynab Khanlarova]], composer [[Eldar Mansurov]] and others signed [[obituary]] and expressed their condolences to Guliyeva's family members:[http://modern.az/az/news/97130/#gsc.tab=0 Prezidentlə baş nazir İlhamə Quliyevanın vəfatı ilə bağlı nekroloq imzaladı] {{Quote frame|''Obituary, 2016'': The memory of the well-known Azerbaijani singer Ilhama Guliyeva will always remain in the hearts of those who loved such sincere person and respected her musical creativity.|align=center}} == Filmography == # [[:az:Toyda görüş|Toyda görüş]], (watch[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cZ1ietSHMMc Toyda Görüş filmi] [[concert film]], 1970) # [[:az:Çiçək yağışı|Çiçək yağışı]], ([[film]], 1971) # [[Göy göl]], ([[concert film]], 1973) # [[:az:Mahnı qanadlarında|Mahnı qanadlarında]], (watch[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HlNQChJu3v0 Mahnı Qanadlarında filmi] {{Infobox State Senator | name=Jake C. Files |image= | birth_date={{birth date and age|1972|3|27}} | birth_place=[[Norman, Oklahoma|Norman]], [[Oklahoma]], U.S. | residence=[[Fort Smith, Arkansas|Fort Smith]]
[[Sebastian County, Arkansas|Sebastian County]]
[[Arkansas]] | death_date= | death_place= | death_cause= | resting_place= | state_senate=Arkansas | district=8th | term_start=January 2013 | term_end=February 9, 2018 | preceded=[[Cecile Bledsoe]] | succeeded=[[Frank Glidewell]] | state_senate2=Arkansas | district2=13th | term_start2=2011 | term_end2=2013 | preceded2= | succeeded2=[[Alan Clark (Arkansas politician)|Alan Clark]] | state_house3=Arkansas | district3=12th | term_start3=January 1999 | term_end3=January 2003 | preceded3= | succeeded3= | party=[[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] | alma_mater=[[Ouachita Baptist University]]
[[Arkansas State University]] | occupation=[[Business]]man | spouse=Michaela Mitchell Files | children=Kate, Liz, and Bella Files | footnotes= }} '''Jake C. Files''' (born March 27, 1972) is a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] politician from [[Fort Smith, Arkansas|Fort Smith]], [[Arkansas]]. Files represented portions of the [[Arkansas River Valley]] in the [[Arkansas House of Representatives]] from 1999 to 2003, and in the [[Arkansas Senate]] from 2011 to 2018. He pleaded guilty in 2018 to wire fraud, bank fraud and money laundering relating to misuse of the state's surplus money and was sentenced to 18 months in prison. ==Background== A native of [[Norman, Oklahoma|Norman]], [[Oklahoma]], Files graduated [[cum laude]] with a [[bachelor's degree]] in [[accounting]] from [[Arkansas State University]] in [[Jonesboro, Arkansas|Jonesboro]]. Previously, he had attended [[Ouachita Baptist University]] in [[Arkadelphia, Arkansas|Arkadelphia]]. He is the owner of FFH Construction, a general construction firm. From 1997 to 2004, he was the president and superintendent of the Fort Smith Christian School. Prior to that, he was hired to help start operations of the Baldor Electric Company plant in [[Ozark, Arkansas|Ozark]], Arkansas, as the accountant and materials manager. He and his wife, the former Michaela K. Mitchell (born 1977), have four children, Kate, Liz, Bella, and Mitchell, and are active members of Grand Avenue Baptist Church, a [[Southern Baptist]] congregation in Fort Smith. The senator [[Coach (sport)|coaches]] [[Little League]] [[baseball]] and [[basketball]]. ==Political life== From 1999 to 2003, he represented District 12 in the [[Arkansas House of Representatives]]. Files was first elected to the State Senate in 2010 in District 13.{{cite web|url=http://www.arkleg.state.ar.us/assembly/2011/Member%20Profiles/Jake%20Files.pdf|title=Jake Files|publisher=arkleg.state.ar.us|accessdate=November 29, 2013}} His district number was switched through [[redistricting]] from District 13 to District 8, effective January 2013, and his district boundaries changed to include most of the cities of [[Greenwood, Arkansas|Greenwood]] and [[Hackett, Arkansas|Hackett]].{{cite web|url=http://votesmart.org/candidate/biography/16268/jake-files#.UplRqBXnYfQ|title=Jake Files' Biography|publisher=votesmart.org|accessdate=November 29, 2013}} He served on Senate committees for Revenue & Taxation, Transportation, Technology, Legislative Affairs, Joint Budget, and Senate Efficiency. He was also a member of the Joint (House and Senate) Legislative Committee on Auditing. He was chairman of the Revenue and Taxation Committee. ==Fraud scandal== In early 2017, Files was accused of submitting false bids for the River Valley Sports Complex, a planned park of softball fields at Chaffee Crossing in [[Fort Smith, Arkansas|Fort Smith]]. Though initially denying the charges,{{cite news|last1=Jordan|first1=Kate|title=State Senator: Claims Of False Bids For Fort Smith Complex Aren’t True|url=http://5newsonline.com/2017/02/20/state-senator-claims-of-false-bids-for-fort-smith-complex-arent-true/ |accessdate=1 March 2017|publisher=KFSM|date=February 20, 2017}} Files pleaded guilty to wire fraud, bank fraud and money laundering in the [[United States District Court for the Western District of Arkansas]] in January 2018.{{ cite web |first= Dave |last= Hughes |title= Arkansas lawmaker pleads guilty to wire fraud, money laundering; governor says senator to resign soon |url= http://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2018/jan/29/arkansas-lawmaker-pleads-guilty-wire-fraud-money-l/?breaking |publisher= Arkansas Democrat-Gazette |date= January 29, 2018 |accessdate= January 30, 2018 }} He resigned his senate seat in February. ===Plea=== The plea agreement says Files and Lee Webb, a member of the [[Sebastian County, Arkansas|Sebastian County]] Election Commission, convinced the City of Fort Smith to appropriate $1.6 million for the project in 2014. Files then created three fictitious companies to bid for the project. He later proposed steering $150,000 of public funds from the state's General Improvement Fund (GIF) to the project.{{cite news|last1=Hammersly|first1=Lisa|title=In dark on bids Arkansas senator submitted, companies say|url=http://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2017/feb/19/in-dark-on-bids-files-submitted-compani/?latest|accessdate=20 February 2017|publisher=Arkansas Democrat-Gazette|date=19 February 2017}} Files had control over the funds, and was chairman of the Senate Revenue and Taxation Committee. He pleaded guilty, and was sentenced to 18 months in prison and ordered to pay $83,900 in restitution.{{cite news|url=https://talkbusiness.net/2018/06/former-sen-jake-files-sentenced-to-18-months-in-prison-judge-calls-violations-egregious/|title=Former Sen. Jake Files sentenced to 18 months in prison, judge calls violations ‘egregious’ (Updated)|author=Michael Tilley|date=June 18, 2018|work=Talk Business & Politics}} {{Portalbar|Biography|Oklahoma|Arkansas|Politics|Conservatism|Education|Business and Economics|Baptist}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{s-start}} {{succession box |before=[[Cecile Bledsoe]] |title=[[Arkansas State Senate|Arkansas State Senator for District 8
(Sebastian County)]] Jake C. Files |years=2013 – February 9, 2018 |after=[[Frank Glidewell]]}} {{succession box |before=Missing |title=[[Arkansas State Senate|Arkansas State Senator for District 13]] Jake C. Files |years=2011–2013 |after=[[Alan Clark (Arkansas politician)|Alan Clark]]}} {{succession box |before=Missing |title=[[Arkansas House of Representatives|Arkansas State Representative for District 12
(Fort Smith)]] Jake C. Files |years=1999–2003 |after=Missing}} {{s-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Files, Jake}} [[Category:1972 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:21st-century American criminals]] [[Category:American fraudsters]] [[Category:American money launderers]] [[Category:Arkansas politicians convicted of crimes]] [[Category:Ouachita Baptist University alumni]] [[Category:Arkansas State University alumni]] [[Category:Members of the Arkansas House of Representatives]] [[Category:Arkansas state senators]] [[Category:Arkansas Republicans]] [[Category:Tea Party movement activists]] [[Category:People from Norman, Oklahoma]] [[Category:Politicians from Fort Smith, Arkansas]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Arkansas]] [[Category:American accountants]] [[Category:American educators]] [[Category:Baptists from Arkansas]] [[Category:21st-century American politicians]] [[Category:Baptists from Oklahoma]]

{{Short description|American painter}} <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Bama1.jpg|300px|right|thumb|''Lee Martin - Standing Star Ranch'' by James Bama]] --> '''James Elliott Bama''' (born April 28, 1926, [[Washington Heights, Manhattan|Washington Heights]], [[New York (state)|New York]])<ref name="Mantle Fielding's">{{cite book|last=Kane|first=Brian M.|title=James Bama: American Realist|year=2006|publisher=Flesk|location=Santa Cruz, CA|isbn=0-9723758-8-0|pages=160}}</ref> is an American [[artist]] known for his realistic paintings and etchings of [[Western United States|Western]] subjects. Life in [[Wyoming]] led to his comment, "Here an artist can trace the beginnings of Western history, see the first buildings, the oldest wagons, saddles and guns, and be up close to the remnants of Indian culture ... And you can stand surrounded by nature's wonders."
==Biography== Born in [[Manhattan]] in 1926, he grew up copying [[Alex Raymond]]'s ''[[Flash Gordon]]'' [[comic strip]]. He had his first professional sale when he was 15, a drawing of [[Yankee Stadium]] in the ''[[New York Journal-American]]''. He graduated from New York's [[The High School of Music and Art|High School of Music and Art]] and entered the [[United States Army Air Corps|Army Air Corps]], working as a mechanic, [[mural]] painter, and physical training instructor.
When discharged from the service, and back in New York City, he studied drawing and anatomy at the [[Art Students League of New York|Art Students League]]. Beginning in 1951, he was an illustrator at New York's Charles E. Cooper Studios for 15 years. His first paperback cover was Nelson Nye's ''A Bullet for Billy the Kid'' (1950). Bama had a 22-year career as a successful [[commercial artist]], producing paperback book covers, movie posters and illustrations for such publications as ''[[Argosy (magazine)|Argosy]]'', ''[[The Saturday Evening Post]]'' and ''[[Reader's Digest]]'', and his numerous clients included the New York Giants football team, the Baseball and Football Halls of Fame and the U.S. Air Force. Beginning with ''The Man of Bronze'' (1964), he did a powerful set of 62 covers for the ''[[Doc Savage]]'' Bantam Books paperbacks, often using as a model actor [[Steve Holland (actor)|Steve Holland]], star of TV's ''Flash Gordon'' (1954–55). He also painted the box cover art for [[Aurora Plastics Corporation|Aurora]]'s monster model kits, including [[King Kong]], [[Frankenstein's monster|Frankenstein]], [[Count Dracula|Dracula]] and [[The Mummy (franchise)|The Mummy]].<ref>[http://www.jdevito.com/tim.htm The Art of Joe DeVito - Tim Lasiuta Interview<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
In 1964 he married Lynne Klepfer, a New York University graduate with an art history major. Two years later, in June, 1966, the couple headed west as guests of artist Bob Meyers at his Circle M ranch near [[Cody, Wyoming]]. Meyers had walked out on his career as a successful Manhattan illustrator with such magazines as ''[[True (magazine)|True]]'' and ''[[The Saturday Evening Post]]'' to run his ranch and paint. After return visits in 1967, the Bamas left New York and moved during September, 1968, into a cabin on Meyers’ ranch. Bama began to paint contemporary Western subjects during the daytime while doing his freelance illustrations in the evenings. He recalled, "I never came out here with the idea to be a Western artist. It just happened, and that’s the way it should be."
In 1970 Bob Meyers was murdered, and his widow Helen moved from the ranch. The Bamas moved to a house on Dunn Creek, Wapiti, 20 miles outside Cody, in 1971. In May, 1971, Bama connected with a New York dealer, prompting his decision to abandon illustration and put his total concentration into the creation of easel paintings. In Wapiti, James and Lynne Bama built a home and studio, moving into it when their son Ben was born in 1977.
His work is collected in ''The Western Art of James Bama'' (Bantam Books, 1975) and ''The Art of James Bama'' (1993). Brian M. Kane's ''James Bama: American Realist'' (Flesk, 2006) has an introduction by [[Harlan Ellison]].
==Style== Bama's art is realism. He sometimes takes advantage of his medium to use lighting techniques—such as [[Butterfly (lighting)|butterfly lighting]]—that would not be practical in a photograph taken under ambient light.
==Awards== Bama was inducted into the Illustrator’s Hall of Fame on June 28, 2000. At the [[Buffalo Bill Historical Center]], when he was the first Honored Artist at the Buffalo Bill Art Show in 2003, Bama commented, "Everything I’ve done — the rodeo, the trappers, the mountain men — has been done around here. The fact that I’m from Cody makes this very significant to me. They’re really honoring Cody and the Buffalo Bill Historical Center."
He was inducted into the Monster Kid Hall Of Fame at [[The Rondo Hatton Classic Horror Awards]].{{Citation needed|date=July 2017}}
==References==
<references/> * Kelton, Elmer. ''The Art of James Bama''. Trumbull, Connecticut: Greenwich Workshop, 1993. * Kane, Brian M. ''James Bama: American Realist''. Flesk Publications, {{ISBN|0-9723758-8-0}}, 2006.
==External links== *[http://www.bighorngalleries.com/bama.htm Big Horn Galleries: James Bama] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20061021205320/http://www.fleskpublications.com/publications/bama/ James Bama: American Realist (2006)]
{{Society of Illustrators' Hall of Fame}} {{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bama, James}} [[Category:1926 births]] [[Category:20th-century American painters]] [[Category:American male painters]] [[Category:21st-century American painters]] [[Category:American magazine illustrators]] [[Category:Animal artists]] [[Category:Art Students League of New York alumni]] [[Category:Artists of the American West]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Cody, Wyoming]] [[Category:United States Army Air Forces soldiers]] [[Category:Artists from New York City]] [[Category:The High School of Music & Art alumni]]

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} [[File:john-hollingshead-1895.jpg|thumb|right|John Hollingshead in 1895]] '''John Hollingshead''' (9 September 1827 – 9 October 1904) was an English theatrical [[impresario]], journalist and writer during the latter half of the 19th century. After a journalism career, Hollingshead managed the [[Alhambra Theatre]] and was later the first manager of the [[Gaiety Theatre, London]]. Hollingshead also wrote several books during his life. An innovative producer, Hollingshead brought [[Gilbert and Sullivan]] together in 1871 to produce their first joint work, a musical [[extravaganza]] called ''[[Thespis (opera)|Thespis]]''. Among other theatrical works that he produced, he mounted a long series of popular [[Victorian burlesques]] at the Gaiety, engaging [[Meyer Lutz]] to compose original scores for them. He also produced operettas, plays and other works. These productions made stars of [[Nellie Farren]] and several others. At the Gaiety, in 1878, Hollingshead was the first theatre manager to light his auditorium with electric lights. ==Life and career== [[File:John Hollingshead.jpg|thumb|right|Hollingshead in an 1870 cartoon]] Hollingshead was born in [[Hoxton]], Greater London, the son of Henry Randall Hollingshead. He was educated at Homerton.{{cite book|last=Anonymous|first=|others=Illustrated by [[s:Author:Frederick Waddy|Frederick Waddy]]|title=Cartoon portraits and biographical sketches of men of the day |url=http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Cartoon_portraits_and_biographical_sketches_of_men_of_the_day/Professor_Owen |accessdate=6 January 2011|year=1873|publisher=Tinsley Brothers|location=London|pages=36–37}} He first worked as a bookkeeper for a soft goods company in London in the early 1850s while publishing political essays on finance and social reform.Hollingshead (1895), P. 73 He soon entered into a partnership as a clothing merchant. During this time, Hollingshead and his friend [[Moy Thomas]] began publishing a penny paper called ''The Mail'' that proved unsuccessful.Hollingshead (1895), P. 83 In 1854, he decided to close his clothing business and begin working as a writer full-time. By 1855, Hollingshead was married with two children.Hollingshead (1895), P. 93 He died in London at the age of 77. ===Journalist and author=== Hollingshead started his journalism career in 1854 under the tutelage of [[Charles Dickens]] at ''Household Words'' magazine and then under [[W. M. Thackeray]] at ''[[Cornhill Magazine]]''.[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9E0DE2D61230E132A25752C1A9669D946597D6CF Obituary in the ''[[New York Times]]''] In 1861, he acted as the "special correspondent" for ''[[The Morning Post]]'' during the London famine. He also wrote essays, short stories and dramatic criticism.{{cite news|author= |title=New Play at the Odeon; Said Not to Be a Good One, But to Be Interesting|date= 3 October 1892|work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F00E0D91E39E033A25750C0A9669D94639ED7CF |accessdate=6 August 2008}} Beginning in 1864, and for several years thereafter, he contributed to ''[[Punch (magazine)|Punch magazine]]'', mostly writing on political topics related to social reform.Spielmann, p. 368 He advocated the principles of Mill and [[Jeremy Bentham]]. One of his best-known essays was an 1857 piece called "The City of Unlimited Paper", which became famous during the monetary panic of 1857. In the 1860s he was on the staff of ''[[Good Words]]'' under [[Norman Macleod (1812–1872)|Norman Macleod]] as editor.{{cite magazine |title=Hollingshead, John|magazine= Who's who biographies, 1901|pages=578–579|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8EcuAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA578}} Hollingshead wrote a number of books from the 1850s into the 1860s, including ''On the canal: a narrative of a voyage from London to Birmingham'' (1858); ''Under Bow Bells'' (1860, a collection of some of his essays),{{cite book|title=Under Bow bells |author=John Hollingshead |year=1860|publisher=Groombridge and sons |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eSkgAAAAMAAJ&dq=%22john+hollingshead%22+%22under+bow+bells%22&printsec=frontcover&source=web&ots=_Z2ZbFtdi4&sig=zAyJB2VoYq8ZE1lC7xCnvYt169I }} ''Rubbing the Gilt Off'' (a collection of his early political essays (1860) ''Odd Journeys'' (1860, a collection of travels),{{cite book |title=Odd journeys in and out of London |author=John Hollingshead |year=1860 |publisher=Groombridge |isbn= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BKICAAAAQAAJ&dq=%22john+hollingshead%22+%22odd+journeys%22&printsec=frontcover&source=web&ots=5S30XjAGf2&sig=snXFbK3eXOFbNiNgKGjyzpWSqCY }} ''Ways of Life'' (1861, a volume of humorous papers), ''Ragged London'' (1861, a collection of his reports for the ''Morning Post''),{{cite book |title=Ragged London in 1861 |author=John Hollingshead |year= |publisher= |isbn=1-4021-8921-4 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hsz9S4a4YL4C&pg=PR3&lpg=PR3&dq=%22john+hollingshead%22+%22odd+journeys%22&source=web&ots=ft-1c6YG7F&sig=KdWsTlRSMpHCf2GohX7kEuOglQg }} and ''Underground London'' (1862). Other publications included a collection of humorous stories entitled ''Rough Diamonds'' and two volumes of miscellaneous essays called ''Today''. He also wrote plays. [[File:John Hollingshead - Entr'acte.png|left|thumb|150px|Hollingshead in 1898]] In the 1880s, Hollingshead returned to writing, producing books mostly about the theatre, including ''Plain English'' (1880),{{cite book |title=Plain English |author=John Hollingshead |year=1880 |publisher=Chatto and Windus |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DoI0AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA117&dq=%22john+hollingshead%22+%22plain+english%22#PPA120,M1 }} and ''Footlights'' (1883).{{cite book |title=Footlights |author=John Hollingshead |year=1883 |publisher=Chapman and Hall, limited |isbn= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=02oOAAAAIAAJ&dq=%22john+hollingshead%22+footlights&printsec=frontcover&source=web&ots=bQMymPBgcA&sig=yrYxlnN4TpyKC_qXD57NcYvt1ts }} Beginning in the 1890s, he wrote a number of memoirs and more books about the theatres that he had managed. In 1892, he also published ''The Story of Leicester Square'', tracing the history, geography and architecture of the London neighbourhood from earliest times through the date of publication. His memoir entitled ''My Lifetime'', published in 1895, explores his life and career through that date. ===Producer and theatre manager=== ====The Alhambra Theatre and theatrical innovations==== In the 1860s, Hollingshead turned to theatre management. He helped establish the [[Alhambra Theatre]] and was the stage manager there from 1865 to 1868, in addition to producing musical pieces and ballets there. He made it famous for its sumptuous staging, alluring [[corps de ballet]] and the notorious front-of-house Promenade bar, where the young ladies of the ballet hinted at more than [[terpsichorean]] pleasure.Stewart, Maurice. "The spark that lit the bonfire", in ''Gilbert and Sullivan News'', The Gilbert and Sullivan Society, London, Spring 2003. [[File:John Hollingshead, So he plays his part.jpg|thumb|right|{{center|[[s:Cartoon portraits and biographical sketches of men of the day/John Hollingshead|So he plays his part]]
as drawn by [[s:Author:Frederick Waddy|Frederick Waddy]] (1872)}}]] During his tenure at the Alhambra, Hollingshead introduced London audiences to the [[Can-Can]].Hollingshead (1895), p. 224 Hollingshead is also credited with inventing the practice of holding general matinées. Hollingshead was one of the first London theatre managers to eliminate fees for programmes and coat check. He left the Alhambra to manage the newly redesigned [[Gaiety Theatre, London|Gaiety Theatre]]. In addition, Hollingshead managed shows at the [[Opera Comique]] from time to time. He produced a revival of Gilbert's ''[[Princess Toto]]'' there in 1881, paired with [[Rutland Barrington]]'s short play, ''Quid Pro Quo''.{{cite book |title=The Story of the Savoy Opera |author=S. J. Adair Fitz-Gerald |year=2006 |publisher=Kessinger Publishing |isbn=1-4286-1306-4 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tXGLes71dGIC&pg=PA17}} ====The Gaiety Theatre==== In 1868, Hollingshead took over the Gaiety Theatre, which had been a large [[music hall]]. The auditorium was rebuilt and, under Hollingshead, it became a venue primarily for musical [[Victorian burlesque|burlesque]], variety, continental [[operetta]], including several operettas by [[Jacques Offenbach]], and light comedy, under Hollingshead's management, from 1868 to 1886. The theatre opened on 21 December 1868, with the successful ''[[Robert the Devil (Gilbert)|Robert the Devil]]'', by [[W. S. Gilbert]], a burlesque of the opera ''[[Robert le Diable (opera)|Robert le Diable]]''.[http://www.adam-matthew-publications.co.uk/digital_guides/gilbert_and_sullivan_part_1/Brief-Chronology.aspx Digital Guide to Gilbert & Sullivan] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071031152934/http://www.adam-matthew-publications.co.uk/digital_guides/gilbert_and_sullivan_part_1/Brief-Chronology.aspx |date=31 October 2007 }} accessed 1 March 2007 Gilbert also wrote ''[[An Old Score]]'' for the theatre in 1869. Another early production was [[Alfred Thompson (librettist)|Alfred Thompson]]'s ''Columbus!, or the Original Pitch in a Merry Key'' (1869).[http://www.gabrielleray.150m.com/ArchivePressText2003/20030208.html Information about the ''Columbus'' burlesque] [[Nellie Farren]] starred in both ''Columbus'' and ''Robert the Devil''. She continued as "Principal Boy" at the Gaiety for the next 25 years, first under Hollingshead and then under [[George Edwardes]]. Other Gaiety stalwarts were [[Edward O'Connor Terry|Edward Terry]], [[Kate Vaughan]] and [[Fred Leslie]]. The theatre's music director, [[Meyer Lutz]], composed or arranged the music for many of its most successful burlesques. [[File:Thespis - Illustrated London News Jan 6 1872.png|400px|thumb|left|Illustration of ''[[Thespis (opera)|Thespis]]'', the first [[Gilbert and Sullivan]] work]] In 1870, [[Henry James Byron]]'s ''Uncle Dick's Darling'' starred a young [[Henry Irving]]. This was the last play that theatre buff [[Charles Dickens]] saw before his death. Other pieces at Hollingshead's Gaiety in 1870 included ''Dot'' ([[Dion Boucicault]]'s version of ''The Cricket on the Hearth''); and ''The Princess of Trebizonde'', based on the [[Jacques Offenbach]] operetta (1870). ''[[Thespis (opera)|Thespis]]'', the first collaboration between [[Gilbert and Sullivan]], played at the theatre in 1871, with Farren as Mercury and [[J. L. Toole]] in the title role. Offenbach's ''[[Les deux aveugles]]'' played in 1872, starring [[Fred Sullivan]]. This was followed by such works as ''Shilly-Shally'' (1872) by [[Anthony Trollope]] and [[Charles Reade]]; ''Antony and Cleopatra'' (1873); and ''The Battle of Life'', (based on [[Charles Dickens]]'s Christmas story of that title). Two other [[Dion Boucicault]] plays produced by Hollingshead's company in the early 1870s were ''Night and Morning'' and ''Led Astray''. Boucicault's ''Don Caesar de Bazan'' was travestied in Byron's ''Little Don Caesar de Bazan''.[http://www.victorianweb.org/mt/theaters/pva234.html Includes a profile of the Gaiety and other Victorian theatres] [[File:Montecristofarren.jpg|right|thumb|200px|Sheet music from ''Monte Cristo, Jr.'']] In the late 1870s, the theatre became the first to install electric lighting on its auditorium. Hollingshead's productions there included ''The Bohemian G-yurl and the Unapproachable Pole'' (1877), Byron's farce ''Little Doctor Faust'' (1878)[http://www.gabrielleray.150m.com/ArchiveTextF/NellieFarren.html Information from Footlight Notes website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091012233616/http://www.gabrielleray.150m.com/ArchiveTextF/NellieFarren.html |date=12 October 2009 }} Byron's ''Handsome Hernani, or The Fatal Penny-Whistle'' (1879);[http://footlightnotes.tripod.com/20050226home.html Information and images regarding ''Handsome Hernani, or The Fatal Penny-Whistle''] and ''Robbing Roy'' (1879). [[Meyer Lutz]]'s ''[[Ali Baba|Ali Baba and The Forty Thieves]]'' was performed in 1880 (Hollingshead had produced a highly successful charity production called ''[[The Forty Thieves]]'' at the Gaiety in 1878), and a burlesque of ''[[Aladdin]]'', by [[Robert Reece]], in 1881. These were followed by ''Little Robin Hood'' (1882), a burlesque by Reece, ''Blue Beard'' (1882), ''Ariel'' (1883, by [[F. C. Burnand]], based on ''[[The Tempest]]''), ''Don Yuan'', Byron's ''Little Don Caesar de Bazan'' (a send-up of Boucicault's play), ''Mazeppa'' (1884), ''[[Little Jack Sheppard]]'' (1885), ''[[Monte Cristo Jr.]]'' (1886), and dozens of others.Plarr, Victor G. ''Men and Women of the Time'' (1898) G. Routledge, London [[John D'Auban]] choreographed the Gaiety burlesques from 1868."Mr. D'Auban's 'Startrap' Jumps". ''The Times'', 17 April 1922, p. 17Biographical file for John D'Auban, list of productions and theatres, [[The Theatre Museum]], London (2009) In addition to these burlesques, the theatre produced comedies such as Congreve's ''Love for Love'', Vanbrugh's ''Relapse'', ''The Grasshopper'' (1877, an adaptation by Hollingshead of [[Henri Meilhac]] and [[Ludovic Halévy]]'s ''La Cigale''),[http://www.whistler.arts.gla.ac.uk/biog/Holl_J.htm Information about ''The Grasshopper''] and a number of farces. Nevertheless, burlesque and risque operettas were the normal fare at the Gaiety. Hollingshead called himself a "licensed dealer in legs, short skirts, French adaptations, [[Shakespeare]], taste and musical glasses."[http://www.arthurlloyd.co.uk/Gaiety.htm Arthur Lloyd Music Hall site (on Gaiety) ''Cuttings''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080104132022/http://www.arthurlloyd.co.uk/Gaiety.htm |date= 4 January 2008 }} accessed 1 March 2007 In 1886, George Edwards took over the lease to the Gaiety. ==Notes== {{reflist|2}} ==References== *Hollingshead, John. ''Alhambra: Theatre of Varieties, Leicester Square'', London: Simpkin, Marshall, Hamilton, Kent & Co. (1893) *Hollingshead, John. [https://books.google.com/books?id=j2NuebFfsScC&dq=%22john+hollingshead%22+my+lifetime ''My Lifetime''], 2 vols., London: Sampson, Low, & Marston (1895) *Hollingshead, John. [https://books.google.com/books?id=CzgOAAAAIAAJ&dq=john+hollingshead+gaiety+chronicles here ''Gaiety Chronicles''], London: A. Constable & Co. (1898) *Hollingshead, John. ''Good Old Gaiety: An Historiette & Remembrance'', London: Gaiety Theatre Co. (1903) *Spielmann, Marion Harry. [https://books.google.com/books?id=o5o4AAAAIAAJ&dq=John+hollingshead ''The History of Punch''], London: Cassell (1895) ==External links== *{{Wikisource author-inline}} *[https://books.google.com/books?id=8EcuAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA578 Hollingshead in the 1907 edition of ''Who's Who''] *[http://www.whistler.arts.gla.ac.uk/biog/Holl_J.htm Information about Hollingshead and Whistler] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hollingshead, John}} [[Category:People associated with Gilbert and Sullivan]] [[Category:English theatre managers and producers]] [[Category:English writers]] [[Category:English male journalists]] [[Category:1827 births]] [[Category:1904 deaths]] [[Category:English male non-fiction writers]]

revision.text:
{{About|the person|places named for him|José Azueta (disambiguation)}} {{Spanish name|Azueta|Abad}} {{Infobox military person |image=AzuetaNHMDF.JPG |caption=Artistic depiction of Mexican Navy Lieutenant José Azueta firing a French [[Hotchkiss machine gun]] in the defense of [[Veracruz]] during the [[United States involvement in the Mexican Revolution|Second U.S. intervention]] of the [[Mexican Revolution]], painting at the Naval Historical Museum in [[Mexico City]] |birth_date={{Birth date|1895|05|02}} |birth_name=José Azueta Abad |birth_place=[[Acapulco]], [[Guerrero]], Mexico |death_date={{death date and age|1914|05|10|1895|05|02}} |death_place=[[Veracruz, Veracruz|Veracruz]], Mexico |allegiance=Mexico |branch=Mexican Navy |rank=Lieutenant |battles=[[Mexican Revolution]]{{KIA}} }} [[Image:Acapulco - Plaza de la H. Escuela Naval Militar (José Azueta)2.JPG|thumb|right|220px|Monument to José Azueta in the Plaza de la H. Escuela Naval Militar in the Parque de La Reina in [[Acapulco]].]]
'''José Azueta Abad''' (May 2, 1895 – May 10, 1914), usually known as '''José Azueta''', was a [[Mexican Navy]] lieutenant who became famous for his role in the [[United States occupation of Veracruz]], where he was fatally wounded. He is one of the most revered national heroes in Veracruz.
==Early life and education== Born in Guerrero on May 2, 1895, son to Commodore Manuel Azueta Perillos and Josefa Abad. Due to the labor of his father in military service, the family moved to the port of [[Veracruz]]. There he completed basic education in José Miguel Macías of Veracruz School where he showed quick progress especially at discipline and behavior. At age 11, his father was promoted to Captain of the ship to the Director of the Naval Academy, at that time, Jose showed his interest and affection for the profession of his father, and in 1909 he began taking classes at the Navy school. At 15, he applied to the Naval Academy and was approved on August 27.
The son of Commodore [[Manuel Azueta]], commander of the [[Veracruz Naval Academy]], [[Lieutenant]] Azueta was wounded on April 21, 1914, the first day of the invasion.
==Career== Azueta was manning a [[machine gun]] placed outside the building, facing the incoming U.S. troops on his own and causing a number of casualties. After having been mortally wounded by [[U.S. Navy]] marksman [[Joseph Gabriel Harner|Joseph G. Harner]], who took several shots at him from about 300 yards away, he was rescued from the battlefield and taken to his home,.<ref>[The Landing at Veracruz:1914'', Jack Sweetman, 1968, p.71]</ref>
After the battle, U.S. [[Admiral]] [[Frank Friday Fletcher]] heard of Azueta's actions and sent word to him via messenger that he (Fletcher) wished to visit the fallen defender and pay his respects. Azueta—through his surgeon and local political activist Dr. [[Roberto Reyes Barreiro]]—sent word to Fletcher refusing the visit, saying "If the American (Fletcher) enters my house, I will either kill him or me." Fletcher then offered to send his personal doctor to take care of him. However, Azueta refused medical services offered by the occupation army and only allowed local Dr. Rafael Cuervo Xicoy to treat him. Dr. Xicoy lacked medical supplies to assist Azueta properly. At the time of his death, Lt. Azueta was being cared for by the surgeon Reyes Barreiro.
On April 24, Lieutenant Azueta was promoted immediately to [[Captain (naval)|captain]] by the President of the Republic <!---Huerta, presumably?---> for his performance in combat. On April 29, he was awarded a gold medal with the Decoration of the Second U.S. Invasion. Again on May 1, he was issued the [[Military decorations of Mexico|3rd Class Military Merit medal]].
Azueta died of his wounds on May 10, Mexico's Mother's Day. During his funeral hundreds of citizens marched holding his coffin on their shoulders to the city's cemetery in open defiance to directives from the occupation army forbidding assembly.
==Legacy== [[Image:José Azueta - herido - May-1914.jpg|thumb|right|José Azueta, hospitalized ''([[General National Archive (Mexico)|Archivo General de la Nación]])'']] The [[municipalities of Mexico|municipalities]] of [[José Azueta, Guerrero]], and [[José Azueta, Veracruz]], were named after him.
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080802124334/http://www.semar.gob.mx/historia/marinos.htm#azueta Biography from the Mexican Government] {{es icon}} *[[:es:José Azueta|Spanish Wikipedia]] {{es icon}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Azueta, Jose}} [[Category:Mexican soldiers]] [[Category:Mexican people of Basque descent]] [[Category:People of the Mexican Revolution]] [[Category:People from Acapulco]] [[Category:Military personnel from Guerrero]] [[Category:1914 deaths]] [[Category:1895 births]]

{{pp-semi-protected|small=yes}} {{Use Indian English|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Katrina Kaif | image = Katrina Kaif in 2018.jpg | alt = The image features Katrina Kaif in a blue and white sari | caption = Kaif at an event for [[Kalyan Jewellers]] in 2018 | birth_name = Katrina Turquotte | birth_place = [[Hong Kong]] | height = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1983|7|16}} | residence = Mumbai, India | citizenship = British | occupation = Actress, model | yearsactive = 2003–present }} '''Katrina Kaif''' ({{IPA-hns|kəˈʈriːnaː ˈkɛːf|pron}}, born '''Katrina Turquotte''', 16 July 1983) is an English actress who works in [[Bollywood|Hindi films]].{{cite news|last=Hafeez |first=Mateen |title=Working in Bollywood for years, but shy of citizenship? |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Working-in-Bollywood-for-years-but-shy-of-citizenship/articleshow/6458769.cms?referral=PM |accessdate=1 March 2014 |work=The Times of India |date=30 August 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160117202653/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Working-in-Bollywood-for-years-but-shy-of-citizenship/articleshow/6458769.cms?referral=PM |archivedate=17 January 2016 |df= }} Despite receiving mixed reviews from critics for her acting prowess, she has established herself in Bollywood and is one of India's highest-paid actresses. Born in Hong Kong, Kaif and her family lived in several countries before she moved to [[London]]. She received her first modelling assignment as a teenager and later pursued a career as a fashion model. At a fashion show in London, filmmaker [[Kaizad Gustad]] spotted Kaif and decided to cast her in ''[[Boom (film)|Boom]]'' (2003), a critical and commercial failure. While filming in India, Kaif received modelling assignments and established a successful modelling career. However, filmmakers were hesitant to cast her due to her poor command of Hindi. After appearing in the Telugu film, ''[[Malliswari (2004 film)|Malliswari]]'' (2004), Kaif earned commercial success in Bollywood with the romantic comedies ''[[Maine Pyaar Kyun Kiya?]]'' (2005) and ''[[Namastey London]]'' (2007). She followed with a series of box-office hits, but was criticised for her acting, repetitive roles and inclination to [[Androcentrism|male-dominated]] films. Kaif's performance in the terrorism drama ''[[New York (film)|New York]]'' (2009) was better received, earning her a [[Filmfare Award for Best Actress]] nomination. After roles in ''[[Ajab Prem Ki Ghazab Kahani]]'' (2009), ''[[Raajneeti]]'' (2010) and ''[[Zindagi Na Milegi Dobara]]'' (2011), she received her second [[Filmfare Awards|Filmfare]] nomination for her performance in ''[[Mere Brother Ki Dulhan]]'' (2011). Kaif's highest-grossing films came with the spy thriller ''[[Ek Tha Tiger]]'' (2012) and its [[Tiger Zinda Hai|2017 sequel]], and the action thriller ''[[Dhoom 3]]'' (2013), all of which rank among the [[List of highest-grossing Indian films|highest-grossing Indian films of all time]]. In addition to acting, Kaif is involved with her mother's charity and participates in stage shows. She is guarded about her personal life, which is a subject of media scrutiny, as is her background. ==Early life and background== Katrina Kaif was born in [[Hong Kong]] with her mother's surname Turquotte (also spelt Turcotte), on 16 July 1983.{{efn|name=A|Although Kaif has said that she was born in 1983, her birth year has been quoted (or inferred) in reliable sources as 1983 or 1984.{{cite video|date=12 July 2011 |title=Katrina, Hrithik Do A Jig At India TV Broadcast Centre |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=maiuTjFv3-Y&feature=youtu.be&t=14m27s |publisher=YouTube |quote=Event occurs at 14:27 |accessdate=3 August 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130929024201/http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=maiuTjFv3-Y&feature=youtu.be&t=14m27s |archivedate=29 September 2013 |df= }}{{cite news|last=Lalwani|first=Vickey|title=Salman Khan's there for me: Katrina Kaif|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-06-29/news-interviews/29716644_1_yash-chopra-priyanka-film|accessdate=4 October 2013|work=[[The Times of India]]|date=29 June 2011}}{{cite web|title=Katrina Kaif turns 30! |url=http://zeenews.india.com/entertainment/celebrity/katrina-kaif-turns-30_139135.html |publisher=[[Zee News]] |accessdate=28 February 2014 |date=18 July 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131231152836/http://zeenews.india.com/entertainment/celebrity/katrina-kaif-turns-30_139135.html |archivedate=31 December 2013 |df= }}{{cite web|title=Katrina Kaif welcomes plans to target false claims in ad world |url=http://zeenews.india.com/entertainment/celebrity/katrina-kaif-welcomes-plans-to-target-false-claims-in-ad-world_150321.html |publisher=Zee News |accessdate=28 February 2014 |date=5 February 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140206020845/http://zeenews.india.com/entertainment/celebrity/katrina-kaif-welcomes-plans-to-target-false-claims-in-ad-world_150321.html |archivedate= 6 February 2014 |df= }}}}{{cite news|last=Bamzai |first=Kaveree |title=Kat who stole the cream |url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/the-rise-of-bollywood-beauty-katrina-kaif/1/127282.html |work=India Today |accessdate=21 September 2013 |date=28 January 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130923081231/http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/the-rise-of-bollywood-beauty-katrina-kaif/1/127282.html |archivedate=23 September 2013 |df= }}{{cite news|title=Happy Birthday Katrina: Ranbir plans big bash for lady love at Barcelona |url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/happy-birthday-katrina-kaif-turns-30/1/291546.html |work=[[India Today]] |accessdate=5 July 2014 |date=16 July 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714130255/http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/happy-birthday-katrina-kaif-turns-30/1/291546.html |archivedate=14 July 2014 |df= }}{{cite news|title=Katrina Kaif: Lesser known facts |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/hindi/bollywood/Katrina-Kaif-Lesser-known-facts/photostory/33609536.cms |accessdate=12 June 2014 |work=The Times of India |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140418050244/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/hindi/bollywood/Katrina-Kaif-Lesser-known-facts/photostory/33609536.cms |archivedate=18 April 2014 |df= }} According to the actress, her father (Mohammed Kaif) is a British businessman of [[Kashmiri people|Kashmiri]] descent and her mother (Suzanne, also spelt Susanna) is an English lawyer and charity worker.{{cite news|title=Tees Maar Khan: A British Bollywood Barbie!|url=http://www.express.co.uk/entertainment/films/224986/Tees-Maar-Khan-A-British-Bollywood-Barbie|accessdate=1 March 2014|work=[[Daily Express]]|date=23 January 2011}}{{cite news|title=The rise and rise of Katrina Kaif |url=http://mumbaimirror.com/others/sunday-read/The-rise-and-rise-of-Katrina-Kaif/articleshow/16169102.cms |accessdate=12 October 2013 |work=[[Mumbai Mirror]] |date=2 October 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131014074135/http://mumbaimirror.com/others/sunday-read/The-rise-and-rise-of-Katrina-Kaif/articleshow/16169102.cms |archivedate=14 October 2013 |df= }}{{cite news|last=Varma|first=Uttara|title=‘I am hundred per cent Indian ... my Hindi is pretty good’|url=http://archive.indianexpress.com/news/-i-am-hundred-per-cent-indian-...-my-hindi-is-pretty-good-/487326/0|accessdate=22 February 2014|work=[[The Indian Express]]|date=12 July 2009}} She has seven siblings: three elder sisters (Stephanie, Christine, and Natasha), three younger sisters (Melissa, Sonia, and Isabel) and an elder brother, Michael. Isabelle Kaif is also a model and actress.{{cite web|title=Isabel Kaif: 10 facts you probably didn't know about Katrina Kaif's sister |url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/isabel-kaif-10-facts-you-probably-didnt-know-about-katrina-kaifs-sister/453219-8-66.html |publisher=[[CNN-IBN]] |accessdate=30 May 2014 |date=20 February 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140302195032/http://ibnlive.in.com/news/isabel-kaif-10-facts-you-probably-didnt-know-about-katrina-kaifs-sister/453219-8-66.html |archivedate= 2 March 2014 |df= }} Kaif's parents divorced when she was a child, and her father moved to the United States. She said her father had no influence on Kaif or her siblings while they were growing up, and they were raised by their mother.{{cite news|last=Chaturvedi |first=Anshul |title=I'm not dumb: Katrina |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/hindi/bollywood/news-interviews/Im-not-dumb-Katrina/articleshow/7162203.cms |accessdate=1 March 2014 |work=The Times of India |date=26 December 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140505123041/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/hindi/bollywood/news-interviews/Im-not-dumb-Katrina/articleshow/7162203.cms |archivedate= 5 May 2014 |df= }} On her father's absence in her life, Kaif stated: "When I see friends who have wonderful fathers who are like pillars of support for their families, I say, if only I had that. But instead of complaining, I should be grateful for all the other things I have". In a 2009 interview with ''[[The Indian Express]]'', she said she was not in touch with her father. [[File:Katrina Kaif with her mother.jpg|thumb|alt=A woman is sitting next to an older woman in a crowded room. The younger woman is sitting on the right wearing a white dress, while the older woman is wearing a black dress.|Kaif with her mother at the [[People's Choice Awards India]], 2012|268x268px]] Kaif says that her mother decided to "dedicate her life to social causes", which led to the family's relocation to a number of countries for varying lengths of time:
Our transitions in growing up were—from Hong Kong where I was born, to China, then to Japan, and from Japan by boat to France ... After France, Switzerland—and I'm cutting out many East European countries where we were for only a few months each—then Poland in [[Kraków]] ... After that we went to Belgium, then to Hawaii, which was a short time, and then came to London.
Due to their frequent relocation, Kaif and her siblings were [[Homeschooling|home-schooled]] by a series of tutors.{{cite journal |last=Chaudhury |first=Shoma |url=http://archive.tehelka.com/story_main40.asp?filename=hub041008The_man.asp |title=The Man Of The Family |journal=[[Tehelka]] |volume=5 |issue=39 |accessdate=18 June 2014 |date=4 October 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714141625/http://archive.tehelka.com/story_main40.asp?filename=hub041008The_man.asp |archivedate=14 July 2014 |df= }} Although she is thought to have grown up in London, she lived there for only three years before moving to India. According to Kaif, she then changed her surname to her father's because she thought it would be easier to pronounce.{{cite news|title=My name’s Turquotte: Katrina |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/bollywood/news-interviews/My-names-Turquotte-Katrina/articleshow/4986854.cms?referral=PM |accessdate=12 October 2013 |work=The Times of India |date=9 September 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160215032330/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/bollywood/news-interviews/My-names-Turquotte-Katrina/articleshow/4986854.cms?referral=PM |archivedate=15 February 2016 |df= }} Kaif's paternal parentage has been questioned by some members of the film industry. In a 2011 interview with ''[[Mumbai Mirror]]'', ''[[Boom (film)|Boom]]'' producer [[Ayesha Shroff]] accused Kaif of fabricating her history: "We created an identity for her. She was this pretty young English girl, and we gave her the Kashmiri father and thought of calling her Katrina Kazi. We thought we'd give her some kind of Indian ancestry, to connect with the audience ... But then we thought that Kazi sounded too ... religious? ... [[Mohammad Kaif]] was at the top, and so we said, Katrina Kaif sounds really great". Kaif called Shroff's comments "hurtful". ==Career== ===Modelling and early film work=== [[File:Katrina Kaif- 2006 IIFA Awards.jpg|thumb|left|upright=0.9|alt=A woman is smiling away from the camera.|Kaif at the [[7th IIFA Awards|2006 IIFA Awards]]]] At the age of fourteen, Kaif won a beauty contest in Hawaii, and received her first modelling assignment in a jewellery campaign.{{cite news|last=Reddy |first=T.K. |title=Cool Kat comes to Chennai |url=http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/mp/2003/07/15/stories/2003071500180100.htm |accessdate=21 September 2013 |work=[[The Hindu]] |date=15 July 2003 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130911060648/http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/mp/2003/07/15/stories/2003071500180100.htm |archivedate=11 September 2013 |df= }} She subsequently modelled professionally in London, working for freelance agencies and appearing regularly at [[London Fashion Week]]. At a fashion show Kaif attracted the attention of London-based filmmaker [[Kaizad Gustad]]. He selected her for a role in the English-[[Bollywood|Hindi]] [[Erotic thriller|erotic]] [[heist film]] ''Boom'' as part of an ensemble cast that included [[Amitabh Bachchan]], [[Gulshan Grover]], [[Jackie Shroff]], [[Madhu Sapre]] and [[Padma Lakshmi]].{{cite news|last=Renuka |first=Methil |title=She's got the look |url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/katrina-kaif-to-be-one-of-three-leading-ladies-in-kaizad-gustads-heist-film-boom/1/219881.html |work=India Today |accessdate=21 September 2013 |date=6 May 2002 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130923085749/http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/katrina-kaif-to-be-one-of-three-leading-ladies-in-kaizad-gustads-heist-film-boom/1/219881.html |archivedate=23 September 2013 |df= }}{{cite news|last=Mukherjee |first=Madhureeta |title=Katrina booms in Bollywood |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/hindi/bollywood/news-interviews/Katrina-booms-in-Bollywood/articleshow/22997.cms |accessdate=3 March 2014 |work=The Times of India |date=16 June 2003 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160215032338/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/hindi/bollywood/news-interviews/Katrina-booms-in-Bollywood/articleshow/22997.cms |archivedate=15 February 2016 |df= }} While filming in India, Kaif received other offers and decided to stay in the country.{{cite news|last=Pathiyan |first=Priya |title='I'm not involved with Salman Khan' |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/articleshow/40363538.cms |accessdate=16 March 2003 |work=The Times of India |date=16 March 2003 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040905203940/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/articleshow/40363538.cms |archivedate= 5 September 2004 |df= }} In 2003, she received notice as a model after walking the ramp for [[Rohit Bal]] at the [[India Fashion Week]]{{cite web|last=Menon |first=Sita |title=Katrina's beautiful, and she knows it |url=http://www.rediff.com/news/2003/jul/22katrina.htm |date=21 July 2003 |publisher=[[Rediff.com]] |accessdate=21 September 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130923071622/http://www.rediff.com/news/2003/jul/22katrina.htm |archivedate=23 September 2013 |df= }} and appeared in the first [[Kingfisher Calendar]].{{cite news|last=Banerjee|first=Chetna K.|title=Movers, shakers & sizzlers|url=http://www.tribuneindia.com/2003/20031228/spectrum/main2.htm|accessdate=3 March 2014|work=[[The Tribune (Chandigarh)|The Tribune]]|date=28 December 2003|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130310022439/http://www.tribuneindia.com/2003/20031228/spectrum/main2.htm|archivedate=10 March 2013}} Kaif soon established a successful modelling career in India after endorsing brands such as [[Coca-Cola]], [[LG Corp|LG]], [[Fevicol]] and [[Samsung]].{{cite news|title=Haute route to success |url=http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/mp/2003/08/07/stories/2003080700090200.htm |accessdate=21 September 2013 |work=The Hindu |date=7 August 2003 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121108053228/http://hindu.com/thehindu/mp/2003/08/07/stories/2003080700090200.htm |archivedate= 8 November 2012 |df= }} Kaif's career as a model led to anticipation surrounding her Bollywood debut. ''Boom'' (2003) had its first screening at the [[2003 Cannes Film Festival|Cannes Film Festival]], and was heavily promoted at the event.{{cite news|last=Bamzai |first=Kaveree |title=Vava voom |url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/kaizad-gustad-seems-to-be-on-the-roll-with-boom/1/205880.html |accessdate=3 March 2014 |work=India Today |date=14 July 2003 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140303050032/http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/kaizad-gustad-seems-to-be-on-the-roll-with-boom/1/205880.html |archivedate= 3 March 2014 |df= }}{{cite news|title=It’s Boom time for glamour|url=http://www.tribuneindia.com/2003/20030803/spectrum/spotlite.htm|accessdate=20 April 2014|work=The Tribune|date=3 August 2003|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051203192620/http://www.tribuneindia.com/2003/20030803/spectrum/spotlite.htm|archivedate=3 December 2005}} ''Boom'' was a commercial and critical failure.{{cite news|title=Always knew Katrina Kaif would be superstar, says 'Boom' director |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/bollywood/news-interviews/Always-knew-Katrina-Kaif-would-be-superstar-says-Boom-director/articleshow/21778559.cms?referral=PM |accessdate=22 October 2013 |work=The Times of India |date=12 August 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160215035405/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/bollywood/news-interviews/Always-knew-Katrina-Kaif-would-be-superstar-says-Boom-director/articleshow/21778559.cms?referral=PM |archivedate=15 February 2016 |df= }}{{cite news |last=Bansal |first=Robin |title=Kat’s Boom days are back to haunt her |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/entertainment/bollywood/kat-s-boom-days-are-back-to-haunt-her/article1-671317.aspx |accessdate=24 March 2014 |work=[[Hindustan Times]] |date=9 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140324110934/http://www.hindustantimes.com/entertainment/bollywood/kat-s-boom-days-are-back-to-haunt-her/article1-671317.aspx |archivedate=24 March 2014 |df= }} Kaif's enactment of a supermodel ensnared in the [[India Mafia|Mumbai underworld]] was poorly received, with Ziya U. Salam of ''[[The Hindu]]'' attributing the weak performances of the film's leading ladies to "the vacuity of their expressions".{{cite news|last=Salam |first=Ziya U. |title=Situations vacant |url=http://www.hindu.com/mp/2004/01/01/stories/2004010100180100.htm |accessdate=3 March 2014 |work=The Hindu |date=1 January 2004 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121106105804/http://www.hindu.com/mp/2004/01/01/stories/2004010100180100.htm |archivedate= 6 November 2012 |df= }} ''[[Hindustan Times]]'' reported that after ''Boom''{{'}}s release, Kaif was written off due to her poor [[Hindi]] and thick British accent.{{cite news |title=Katrina on top with six hits in a row: critics |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/news-feed/archives/katrina-on-top-with-six-hits-in-a-row-critics/article1-335506.aspx |accessdate=15 June 2013 |work=Hindustan Times |date=3 September 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131022163845/http://www.hindustantimes.com/news-feed/archives/katrina-on-top-with-six-hits-in-a-row-critics/article1-335506.aspx |archivedate=22 October 2013 |df= }} She later dismissed the film: "I don't count ''Boom'' among important happenings in my life. When I signed this film, I didn't know much about India and its film audience".{{cite news|title=That's Kat! |url=http://www.hindu.com/mp/2004/07/05/stories/2004070500870100.htm |accessdate=21 September 2013 |work=The Hindu |date=5 July 2004 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130923074213/http://www.hindu.com/mp/2004/07/05/stories/2004070500870100.htm |archivedate=23 September 2013 |df= }} Although Kaif was offered a number of modelling assignments, filmmakers were hesitant to cast her because of her poor command of Hindi.{{cite web|title=When John Abraham made Katrina Kaif cry|url=http://movies.ndtv.com/bollywood/when-john-abraham-made-katrina-kaif-cry-254720|publisher=[[NDTV]]|date=14 August 2012|accessdate=21 September 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130928224457/http://movies.ndtv.com/bollywood/when-john-abraham-made-katrina-kaif-cry-254720|archivedate=28 September 2013}} In one instance, [[Mahesh Bhatt]] replaced her with [[Tara Sharma]] in ''[[Saaya (2003 film)|Saaya]]'' (2003) as he found her an "inconsistent performer".{{cite web|last=Lalwani |first1=Vickey |title=Will Saaya repeat Raaz's success? |url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/2003/mar/03saaya.htm |publisher=Rediff.com |date=3 March 2003 |accessdate=4 December 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141213002527/http://www.rediff.com/movies/2003/mar/03saaya.htm |archivedate=13 December 2014 |df= }} Subsequently, Kaif began working on her diction through Hindi classes. After the failure of her first Bollywood project, Kaif appeared in the [[Telugu cinema|Telugu film]] ''[[Malliswari (2004 film)|Malliswari]]'' (2004). With [[Daggubati Venkatesh]], she played the title role of a princess forced to flee from her murderous caretaker. Kaif received a reported {{INRConvert|7.5|m}} for the film, the highest salary for a [[Cinema of South India|South Indian]] film actress at the time. Despite negative reviews for her acting, ''Malliswari'' was a profitable venture.{{cite web|title=South India`s new faces |url=http://www.sify.com/movies/south-india-s-new-faces-imagegallery-0-events-jdwmCvijjggsi.html |publisher=Sify |accessdate=1 March 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140716022822/http://www.sify.com/movies/south-india-s-new-faces-imagegallery-0-events-jdwmCvijjggsi.html |archivedate=16 July 2014 |df= }}{{cite news|last=Pillai |first=Shreedhar |title="Malliswari" mania |url=http://www.hindu.com/mp/2004/02/19/stories/2004021900960300.htm |accessdate=21 September 2013 |work=The Hindu |date=19 February 2004 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130923013049/http://www.hindu.com/mp/2004/02/19/stories/2004021900960300.htm |archivedate=23 September 2013 |df= }} ===Breakthrough (2005–2008)=== In 2005, Kaif appeared briefly as [[Abhishek Bachchan]]'s girlfriend in [[Ram Gopal Varma]]'s [[political thriller]] ''[[Sarkar (film)|Sarkar]]''.{{cite web|last=Jha |first=Subhash K. |title=Katrina’s voice dubbed again |url=http://www.sify.com/movies/katrinas-voice-dubbed-again-news-bollywood-kkfv1Lbecbbsi.html |publisher=Sify |accessdate=28 March 2014 |date=25 July 2005 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140717013629/http://www.sify.com/movies/katrinas-voice-dubbed-again-news-bollywood-kkfv1Lbecbbsi.html |archivedate=17 July 2014 |df= }} She next featured alongside [[Salman Khan]], [[Sushmita Sen]] and [[Sohail Khan]] in ''[[Maine Pyaar Kyun Kiya?]]'', a film she considered her "first real step into Bollywood".{{cite news |last=Jha |first=Subhash K. |title=Adi is my kind of director: Katrina |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/news-feed/nm14/adi-is-my-kind-of-director-katrina/article1-133690.aspx |accessdate=10 December 2014 |work=Hindustan Times |date=3 August 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141216143049/http://www.hindustantimes.com/news-feed/nm14/adi-is-my-kind-of-director-katrina/article1-133690.aspx |archivedate=16 December 2014 |df= }} Directed by [[David Dhawan]], the film was a successful remake of the romantic comedy ''[[Cactus Flower (film)|Cactus Flower]]''.{{cite web|last=Jha |first=Subhash K. |title='We need laughter in our lives' |url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/2004/jul/29david.htm |date=29 July 2004 |publisher=Rediff.com |accessdate=23 October 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029191922/http://www.rediff.com/movies/2004/jul/29david.htm |archivedate=29 October 2013 |df= }}{{cite web|title=Box office cold to Bipasha's sizzle |url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/2005/aug/23box.htm |date=23 August 2005 |publisher=Rediff.com |accessdate=23 October 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029190549/http://www.rediff.com/movies/2005/aug/23box.htm |archivedate=29 October 2013 |df= }} For her role as a suicidal model, Kaif received the [[Stardust Award for Breakthrough Performance – Female]].{{cite news|last=Bose|first=Derek|title=Director’s choice|url=http://www.tribuneindia.com/2009/20090228/saturday/main1.htm|accessdate=29 June 2014|work=The Tribune|date=28 February 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100830001547/http://www.tribuneindia.com/2009/20090228/saturday/main1.htm|archivedate=30 August 2010 }} According to Sukanya Verma of [[Rediff.com]], "Katrina's [[Disney Princess#Disney Princesses|Disney princess]]-like charm adds to her adorable screen presence".{{cite web|last=Verma |first=Sukanya |title=David Dhawan does it again with MPKK |url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/2005/jul/15mpkk.htm |publisher=Rediff.com |accessdate=21 September 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130923094202/http://www.rediff.com/movies/2005/jul/15mpkk.htm |archivedate=23 September 2013 |df= }} Kaif followed with a small part in her second Telugu film, ''[[Allari Pidugu]]''.{{cite news|title=Commercial potboiler |url=http://www.hindu.com/2005/10/08/stories/2005100806350200.htm |accessdate=21 September 2013 |work=The Hindu |date=8 October 2005 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130925143908/http://www.hindu.com/2005/10/08/stories/2005100806350200.htm |archivedate=25 September 2013 |df= }} In 2006, she appeared with [[Akshay Kumar]] for the first of many films in [[Raj Kanwar]]'s unsuccessful ''[[Humko Deewana Kar Gaye]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficeindia.com/showProd.php?itemCat=212&catName=MjAwNg== |title=Box Office 2006 |publisher=[[Box Office India]] |accessdate=21 September 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131014132118/http://boxofficeindia.com/showProd.php?itemCat=212&catName=MjAwNg%3D%3D |archivedate=14 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }} a story of two like-minded strangers who fall in love despite being engaged to others. [[Sify]] wrote that Kaif was "passably competent in a tailor-made role, giving a mild emotional spin to a couple of scenes" but was overshadowed by her supporting actresses.{{cite web |title=Movie Review: Humko Deewana Kar Gaye |url=http://www.sify.com/movies/bollywood/preview.php?ctid=5&cid=2425&id=14185919 |publisher=Sify |accessdate=10 July 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140717000538/http://www.sify.com/movies/bollywood/preview.php?ctid=5&cid=2425&id=14185919 |archivedate=17 July 2014 |df= }} Kaif also appeared with [[Mammootty]] in the [[Malayalam cinema|Malayalam]] [[Crime fiction|crime thriller]] ''[[Balram vs. Tharadas]]'',{{cite web|title=Good cinema should excite the minds |url=http://www.sify.com/movies/malayalam/interview.php?id=14196231&cid=2406 |publisher=Sify |accessdate=22 September 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141024045841/http://www.sify.com/movies/malayalam/interview.php?id=14196231&cid=2406 |archivedate=24 October 2014 |df= }} in which Rishi Raj Singh of ''The Hindu'' called her performance "marvellous".{{cite news|last=Singh |first=Rishi R. |title=A crime thriller from I.V. Sasi |url=http://www.hindu.com/2006/05/02/stories/2006050200940200.htm |accessdate=22 September 2013 |work=The Hindu |date=2 May 2006 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927055745/http://www.hindu.com/2006/05/02/stories/2006050200940200.htm |archivedate=27 September 2013 |df= }} Kaif's career prospects changed in 2007, when she appeared in four Bollywood hits.{{cite news|last=Ghosh |first=Debasmita |title=From Boom to Dhoom: Katrina Kaif's best movies |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/Entertainment/Bollywood/From-Boom-to-Dhoom-Katrina-Kaif-s-best-movies/Article1-1127029.aspx |accessdate=22 February 2014 |work=Hindustan Times |date=25 September 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140221125944/http://www.hindustantimes.com/entertainment/bollywood/from-boom-to-dhoom-katrina-kaif-s-best-movies/article1-1127029.aspx |archivedate=21 February 2014 |df= }} In an interview with ''The Indian Express'', she called [[Vipul Amrutlal Shah]]'s romantic comedy ''[[Namastey London]]'' a milestone, saying that "for the first time, [she] had a dominating role". Kaif used her life in London as a reference for her role as a spoilt [[British Indian]] girl intent on marrying her self-centred British boyfriend, despite her parents' disapproval.{{cite news|title=The other Kaif |url=http://www.hindu.com/mp/2007/03/22/stories/2007032200830100.htm |accessdate=22 September 2013 |work=The Hindu |date=22 March 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927225418/http://www.hindu.com/mp/2007/03/22/stories/2007032200830100.htm |archivedate=27 September 2013 |df= }} Although critics expressed mixed views on the film,{{cite news |last=Kotwani |first=Hiren |title=Vipul Shah defends Namastey London |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/News-Feed/Bollwood/Vipul-Shah-defends-Namastey-London/Article1-212487.aspx |accessdate=22 September 2013 |work=Hindustan Times |date=29 March 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130929235303/http://www.hindustantimes.com/News-Feed/Bollwood/Vipul-Shah-defends-Namastey-London/Article1-212487.aspx |archivedate=29 September 2013 |df= }} Sukanya Verma wrote that Kaif "suits the role to the T" and "brings the zingy mix of her character alive with style and substance".{{cite web|last=Verma |first=Sukanya |title=Namastey London is a fun ride |url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/2007/mar/23nl.htm |date=23 March 2007 |publisher=Rediff.com |accessdate=22 September 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927213900/http://www.rediff.com/movies/2007/mar/23nl.htm |archivedate=27 September 2013 |df= }} Kaif's chemistry with co-star Akshay Kumar was particularly well received, with [[Nikhat Kazmi]] of ''[[The Times of India]]'' calling their casting "refreshing".{{cite news|last=Kazmi |first=Nikhat |title=Namastey London |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/movie-reviews/hindi/Namastey-London/movie-review/1802925.cms |accessdate=22 September 2013 |work=The Times of India |date=24 March 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131222013623/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/movie-reviews/hindi/Namastey-London/movie-review/1802925.cms |archivedate=22 December 2013 |df= }} Taran Adarsh from [[Bollywood Hungama]] mentioned “Katrina is a revelation. The actor surprised you with a confident performance in ''[[Humko Deewana Kar Gaye]]'' and now, in [[Namastey London|''Namaste London'']], she comes up with a spirited performance yet again.
