{{distinguish|text=another [[Seinfeld]] episode, "[[The Soup (Seinfeld)|The Soup]]"}} {{Infobox television episode | title = The Soup Nazi | series = Seinfeld | image = | caption = | season = 7 | episode = 6 | airdate = November 2, 1995 | production = 706 | writer = [[Spike Feresten]] | director = [[Andy Ackerman]] | guests = * [[Wayne Knight]] as [[Newman (Seinfeld)|Newman]] * [[Heidi Swedberg]] as [[Susan Ross]] * [[Larry Thomas (actor)|Larry Thomas]] as Yev Kassem/The Soup Nazi * [[Thom Barry]] as Building Superintendent * [[Steve Hytner]] as Bania * [[Ana Gasteyer]] as Woman * [[Alexandra Wentworth]] as Sheila * [[John Paragon]] as Cedric * [[Yul Vazquez]] as Bob * [[Vince Malocchi]] as Furniture Guy * Michael Michaud as Customer | season_article = Seinfeld (season 7) | episode_list = List of Seinfeld episodes | prev = [[The Hot Tub]] | next = [[The Secret Code (Seinfeld)|The Secret Code]] }} "'''The Soup Nazi'''" is the 116th episode of the [[NBC]] sitcom ''[[Seinfeld]]'', which was the sixth episode of the seventh season. It first aired in the United States on November 2, 1995.
The Soup Nazi is also the nickname of the eponymous character, Yev Kassem, played by [[Larry Thomas (actor)|Larry Thomas]]. The term "[[Nazi]]" is used as an [[Reductio ad Hitlerum|exaggeration]] of the excessively strict regimentation he constantly demands of his patrons ([[cf.]] ''[[Grammar Nazi]]'').<ref>{{cite web|title=Top 15 Seinfeld Food Related Episodes|publisher=Eating the Road|url=http://eatingtheroad.wordpress.com/2009/12/18/top-15-seinfeld-food-related-episodes/|accessdate=July 13, 2012}}</ref>
==Plot== [[Jerry Seinfeld (character)|Jerry]], [[George Costanza|George]] and [[Elaine Benes|Elaine]] visit a new soup stand [[Cosmo Kramer|Kramer]] has been praising. Jerry explains that the owner, Yev Kassem, is known as the "Soup Nazi" due to his temperament and insistence on a strict manner of behavior while placing an order.
At the soup stand, George tells Kassem that he didn't receive any bread with his order. Kassem says bread is two dollars extra, even though George rightfully points out that the other customers received free bread, at which Kassem spitefully pushes the price up to three dollars. When George complains again, Kassem decrees "No soup for you!" George's order is quickly taken away and his money returned.
En route to the soup stand with Jerry and George, Elaine notices a guy on the sidewalk with a giant armoire for sale. She decides to forgo the soup in favor of buying the armoire. However, her [[building superintendent]] informs her that furniture move-ins are not allowed on Sundays, so she asks Kramer to watch the armoire and promises to get soup from Kassem for him in return.
On a subsequent visit, George successfully manages to buy soup (bread came with it this time), but Elaine, having ignored Jerry's advice on how to order, quickly draws Kassem's ire and she is banned for a year. During this time, two thieves (Bob and Cedric) intimidate Kramer and steal the armoire.
Later, Jerry and his current girlfriend Sheila ([[Alexandra Wentworth]]) visit the soup stand. Kassem is repulsed by their public displays of affection, so Jerry disavows knowing Sheila to stay on Kassem's good side. Jerry talks about the situation with George, who has expressed disgust at Jerry's "baby talk". Jerry admits he behaved facetiously with Sheila at the soup stand and vows to redeem himself. George considers this and begins to behave similarly with [[Susan Ross|Susan]] to express his disgust, but Susan instead takes this as a sign of George expressing their love in public.
Some time later, Kramer, who has befriended Kassem, tells him about the armoire theft. Kassem offers him an antique armoire he has in storage as a replacement. Elaine is elated, and goes to Kassem to thank him. When Kassem learns the armoire was for Elaine, he says he would have rather destroyed it than give it to her. Upset, Elaine returns to her apartment with Jerry, where they discover the armoire is filled with Kassem's soup recipes. Elaine returns to the soup stand and confronts Kassem with the recipes, intent on ruining his business in revenge for mistreating her.
Jerry encounters [[Newman (Seinfeld)|Newman]], who is running to get a pot from his apartment. Newman tells him that because of what Elaine said to Kassem, he is closing down his stand and returning to Argentina and giving away whatever soup he has left. Jerry quickly runs home to follow Newman's lead.
==Production== "The Soup Nazi" was [[Spike Feresten]]'s first credited ''Seinfeld'' episode as a writer. The idea for the episode arose when Feresten told [[Jerry Seinfeld]] and [[Larry David]] about New York soup vendor '''[[Al Yeganeh]]''', who was nicknamed "The Soup Nazi." Seinfeld and David laughed and said, "That's a show. Do that as your first show." Feresten's inspiration for the armoire subplot was a New York apartment building where he had lived, which forbade moving furniture on certain days. The armoire thieves were written as [[homosexual]] because Larry David decided that, "Only gay guys would steal an armoire."<ref name=DVDFeresten>"Seinfeld - Season 7" DVD bonus material, in which, during the episode's "Inside Look" featurette, Feresten recounts this story.</ref>
The first cast table reading for "The Soup Nazi" was held on September 28, 1995, and it was filmed before a [[studio audience]] on October 3.<ref name=DVDNotes>"Seinfeld - Season 7" DVD bonus material, "Notes About Nothing" subtitles</ref> In the episode, Elaine ([[Julia Louis-Dreyfus]]) imitates [[Al Pacino]] in ''[[Scent of a Woman (1992 film)|Scent of a Woman]]''. This was done at Jerry Seinfeld's suggestion, even though Louis-Dreyfus had never seen the film.<ref>"Seinfeld - Season 7" DVD bonus material, in which during the episode's "Inside Look" featurette, Louis-Dreyfus recounts this story.</ref>
==The character== [[File:10.1.10LarryThomasByLuigiNovi.jpg|thumb|left|Actor [[Larry Thomas (actor)|Larry Thomas]] polished his portrayal of the Soup Nazi by studying [[Omar Sharif]]'s accent in ''[[Lawrence of Arabia (film)|Lawrence of Arabia]]''.]] The Soup Nazi was portrayed by [[Larry Thomas (actor)|Larry Thomas]], who was nominated for a 1996 Emmy for the role. Thomas, who did not realize that the character was based on a real person, received the inspiration for his portrayal from watching ''[[Lawrence of Arabia (film)|Lawrence of Arabia]]'' and studying [[Omar Sharif]]'s accent.<ref>Schwartz, Lance (May 30, 2012). [http://www.1011now.com/home/headlines/Lances_Journal_The_Soup_Nazi_Visits_Lincoln_May_30_155848075.html "Lance's Journal: The Soup Nazi Visits Lincoln, May 30"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160116004912/http://www.1011now.com/home/headlines/Lances_Journal_The_Soup_Nazi_Visits_Lincoln_May_30_155848075.html# |date=2016-01-16 }}. [[KOLN|10 11]].</ref><ref>Jeffery, Morgan (January 20, 2012). [https://archive.is/20130121165148/http://m.digitalspy.com/tv/tubetalk/a361024/seinfeld-the-greatest-ever-moments.html "'Seinfeld': The greatest ever moments"]. [[Digital Spy]].</ref><ref>[http://www.dailyherald.com/article/20110818/news/708189929/print/ "Hulk, Soup Nazi to greet Wheaton flea market visitors"]. ''[[Daily Herald (Arlington Heights)|Daily Herald]]''. August 18, 2011.</ref>
A stone-faced immigrant chef with a thick [[Joseph Stalin|Stalin]]-esque [[moustache]], he is renowned throughout [[Manhattan]] for his soups. He demands that all customers in his restaurant meticulously follow his strict queuing, ordering, and payment policies. Failure to adhere to his demands brings the stern admonition ("No soup for you!"), whereupon the customer is refunded and denied his or her order. He then yells to the next person in line, "Next!" Elaine parodies this when she reveals that she has his recipes. She says to him, "You're through, Soup Nazi. Pack it up. No more soup for you. NEXT!"<ref>{{cite web|title=Script, Episode 116 - The Soup Nazi|publisher=Seinology.com|url=http://www.seinology.com/scripts/script-116.shtml|accessdate=July 13, 2012}}</ref>
The Soup Nazi has a cameo in the ''Seinfeld'' [[The Finale (Seinfeld)|series finale]], in which his true name is revealed, but which he refuses to spell when asked by District Attorney Hoyt. He is the penultimate witness in the case against Seinfeld, Elaine, George and Kramer, before Babu Bhatt. He tells Hoyt about how he banned Elaine from his shop, only for her to return and ruin his business, forcing him to move to Argentina. Elaine angers him by smugly claiming, "His soup wasn't all that good anyway." During the recess, he is seen serving soup to Robin, Mr. Lipman, Poppie and Babu, all of whom enjoy it. Poppie appears to ask for salt with his soup, whereupon Kassem takes his soup away. He is present and obviously satisfied when Jerry, Elaine, George and Kramer are found guilty and sent to prison.
===Inspiration=== [[Image:Soup-kitchen1.jpg|thumb|250px|The restaurant Soup Kitchen International was the inspiration for this episode of ''Seinfeld''. The restaurant closed in 2004, but has since reopened.]] The character was inspired by '''Ali "Al" Yeganeh''', [[The Original Soup Man|a Persian soup vendor]] who ran [[Soup Kitchen International]] in [[New York City]].<ref>See a profile of Yeganeh in "The Soup Man of 55th Street." ''[[New York Cookbook]]''. ed. Molly O'Neill. Workman Publishing, 1992. pp. 70-71. {{ISBN|1-56305-337-3}}; See one of his recipes on p. 78. of the same work.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://nypost.com/2012/06/22/no-soup-for-you/|title=No soup for you!|first=Kaja|last=Whitehouse|date=June 22, 2012|work=New York Post|accessdate=July 22, 2017}}</ref> Yeganeh has stated on numerous occasions that he is very offended by the "Soup Nazi" moniker.<ref>[http://money.cnn.com/2007/09/13/smbusiness/bc.apfn.ny.soupnazi.ap/?postversion=2007091310 Associated Press via CNN Money] {{dead link|date=September 2013}}</ref>
According to writer [[Spike Feresten]], Jerry Seinfeld and several members of the production team went to Soup Kitchen International for lunch weeks after "The Soup Nazi" aired. Upon recognizing Seinfeld, Yeganeh went into a profanity-filled rant about how the show had "ruined" his business and demanded an apology. Seinfeld allegedly gave what Feresten describes as "the most insincere, sarcastic apology ever given". Obviously having seen the episode, Yeganeh then bellowed, "No soup for you!" and ejected them from the restaurant.<ref>See the Season 7 DVD extras, in which during the episode's ''Inside Look'', Feresten recounts this story.</ref>
According to [[Nora Ephron]]'s DVD commentary, the first pop culture reference to Yeganeh (though not by name) seems to have come years before the ''Seinfeld'' episode, in the 1993 movie ''[[Sleepless in Seattle]]''. In the film, a character playing a writer{{refn|name=sleeplessCharacter|One source says the character was [[Meg Ryan|''Annie'']],<ref name=sleeplessQuotation /> but the script-transcript indicates the character was [[Tom McGowan#Movie credits|''Keith'']].<!-- can somebody with access to the 1993 film verify which character spoke the line please? -->}} [[Sales pitch#Beginning statement|pitches]] a story for [[The Baltimore Sun#Daily|the lifestyle section of the publication]] to [[Rosie O'Donnell|their editor]]: "This man sells the greatest soup you have ever eaten, and he is the meanest man in America. I feel very strongly about this, Becky; it's not just about the soup."<ref name=sleeplessQuotation>{{cite book |author=[[Jennifer Keishin Armstrong]] |title=Seinfeldia: How a Show About Nothing Changed Everything |publisher= [[Simon and Schuster]] |date= July 5, 2016 |isbn= 9781476756127 |page= 130 <!--per entry in the book's index... albeit books.google.com uses pg=PT122--> |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=y9jPCgAAQBAJ&lpg=PT122&pg=PT122&dq=%22sleepless%20in%20seattle%22 }}</ref><!-- various non-WP:RS websites on the internet give a slightly different quotation, if somebody with access to the 1993 film can please confirm what exactly was said: "This man sells the greatest soup you've ever eaten, there's a line around the block, and he is, I am not kidding, the meanest man in America. (pause) I feel strongly about this, Becky. This is not just about soup." -->
==Legacy==
===Advertising=== [[File:EatNParkSoupNazi.jpg|thumb|right|200px|An [[Eat'n Park]] sign featuring the Soup Nazi's catchphrase as a joke in 2016.]] Like [[Jackie Chiles]], the Soup Nazi character (played by Thomas) has appeared in commercials after the end of the series.
* In an advertisement by the corporate lobbying group [[Center for Consumer Freedom]], he denies food to people he considers to be too fat. * Thomas appeared, in character, along with Jerry Seinfeld in a television commercial for [[Acura]] that aired during the 2012 [[Super Bowl]]. In the advertisement, Seinfeld is trying to bribe an ordinary guy to get an Acura, offering him soup from The Soup Nazi, who happily offers "Soup for you!". After Jay Leno beat Jerry Seinfeld in bribing the ordinary guy, the Soup Nazi was seen with Jerry, an alien, and a "[[Munchkin]]" at a restaurant where they are angered at Jay Leno's actions. * In 2013, [[Serbu Firearms]] refused to sell their model BFG-50A semi-automatic .50 rifles to the [[New York City Police Department]] after the passage of the [[NY SAFE Act]] that classified their weapon as an assault rifle.<ref name=NoSerbuForYou>{{cite journal |author=staff |title=Soup Nazi fires off over guns |journal=[[New York Post]] |date=April 2, 2013 |url=http://www.nypost.com/p/pagesix/soup_nazi_fires_off_over_guns_5U9yizmXkDaawodTxMbMaM |accessdate=April 25, 2013}}</ref><ref name=Berman2013>{{cite journal |author=Berman, Jillian |date=April 3, 2013 |title=Larry Thomas, 'Soup Nazi' Actor, Pushes Serbu Firearms To Pull Pro-Gun T-Shirt Featuring His Face |journal=[[The Huffington Post]] |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/04/03/larry-thomas-serbu-firearms_n_3007567.html |accessdate=April 25, 2013}}</ref> Following their refusal to sell the rifles, Serbu had T-shirts printed with an image of the Soup Nazi character with the words "No Serbu For You".<ref name=NoSerbuForYou/> Thomas, a gun control advocate, contacted [[Facebook]] and the [[T-shirt]] printers to have the shirts removed.<ref name=NoSerbuForYou/> Serbu has since removed the image of Thomas and replaced it with one of their founder Mark Serbu.<ref name=SerbuTshirt>{{cite web |author=Higginbotham, David |date=April 9, 2013 |publisher=guns.com |title=No Serbu For You, Soup Nazi Wants His Image Back |url=http://www.guns.com/2013/04/09/no-serbu-for-you-soup-nazi-wants-his-image-back/ |accessdate=April 25, 2013}}</ref>
===In popular culture=== * Larry Thomas appeared as himself in the ''[[Scrubs (TV series)|Scrubs]]'' episode "[[My Self-Examination]]." He denies he is the Soup Nazi when asked by J.D. ([[Zach Braff]]), who then tricks him into saying the catchphrase "No soup for you!" by asking him "What is [the catchphrase] again? It's like, 'You're out of luck in the soup department...'" * Rapper [[Wale (rapper)|Wale]] used lines from the episode as an introduction and outro to his song "The Soup" on his 2010 mixtape ''More About Nothing''. He acts as the Soup Nazi and uses the soup chef's catchphrase "No soup for you!" * In the sitcom ''[[Arrested Development (TV series)|Arrested Development]]'', the crooked housing entrepreneur George Bluth Sr. is charged with signing a development deal with [[Saddam Hussein]], despite the embargo against [[Iraq]]. Bluth claims that he acted in good faith, mistakenly believing that Hussein was Larry Thomas because of his resemblance to the Soup Nazi. This gets referenced in a later episode, where Thomas appears in the role as a [[political decoy]] for Saddam Hussein who has lost his job because of the American invasion of Iraq.
===In-person promotions=== * Larry Thomas has used the character to promote soup kitchens for the homeless.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ktvb.com/home/Seinfeld-star-makes-sure-there-is-soup-for-Boise-homeless-104390699.html |title=Seinfeld star makes sure there is soup for Boise homeless | KTVB.COM Boise |publisher=Ktvb.com |date=October 5, 2010 |accessdate=June 7, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120330150941/http://www.ktvb.com/home/Seinfeld-star-makes-sure-there-is-soup-for-Boise-homeless-104390699.html |archivedate=March 30, 2012 |df= }}</ref> * In July 2012, the "Seinfeld Food Truck" embarked on an eight-stop United States tour. The truck, driven by Larry Thomas, handed out free soup along with other ''Seinfeld''-related food items: Snapple, Twix, Junior Mints, black and white cookies and muffin tops.<ref>{{cite news | first = Zoe | last = Bain | title = Seinfeld "No Soup for You!" Food Truck Tours the Country, Serves Up Nostalgic Snacks | date = July 26, 2012 | url = https://www.delish.com/food/news/a37389/seinfeld-no-soup-for-you-truck/ | work = [[Delish]] | accessdate = May 25, 2018}}</ref> * Thomas was hired by Yeganeh's company in July 2015 to portray the Yev Kassem character as promotion for [[The Original Soup Man|Soupman]] products.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://globenewswire.com/news-release/2015/07/22/754065/10142524/en/The-Original-Soupman-Announces-Seinfeld-Actor-Larry-Thomas-Famous-for-No-Soup-for-You-Episode-to-Jump-Into-the-Soup-Fulltime.html|title=The Original Soupman Announces Seinfeld Actor Larry Thomas Famous for "No Soup for You" Episode to Jump Into the Soup Fulltime|date=July 22, 2015|accessdate=July 22, 2017|work=GlobeNewswire|author=Soupman, Inc.}}</ref>
===Other=== * The episode inspired an actual soup chain, ''Soup Nutsy'', which opened in 1996 in New York City. Though it had no official connection to, or endorsement from, ''Seinfeld'' or its creators, it included specific ''Seinfeld'' references such as describing two of its soups as "Jerry's Favorite" and "Kramer's Favorite", respectively.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/04/nyregion/in-this-corner-soup-nutsy.html In This Corner, Soup Nutsy], Anthony Ramirez, ''[[The New York Times]]'', August 4, 1996</ref> In 1997 it was bought by [[Franchise Concepts]].<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/04/nyregion/soup-nutsy-on-the-move.html Soup Nutsy on the Move], David Chen, ''[[The New York Times]]'', June 4, 1997</ref> A few of its locations remain in [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]] in [[Canada]].<ref>[http://www.soupnutsy.ca/ Soup Nutsy homepage] (retrieved January 28, 2014)</ref> * In August 2009, [[Albert Gonzalez]] was convicted for robbery, being the most prolific hacker of credit cards (130 million). He operated on the Internet using the handle "Soupnazi".<ref>{{cite web|date=August 18, 2009 |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2009/aug/18/nation/na-hacker18 |title=Ex-informant charged with even bigger data theft this time |work = [[Los Angeles Times]]|publisher=[[Associated Press]] |accessdate=June 7, 2013}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * {{IMDb episode|0697782}} * {{Tv.com episode|2358}} * [http://www.realsoupnazi.com/ Soup Nazi Fan Site] * [http://www.seinfeld.com/ Seinfeld - Official Site] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071011141701/http://mrmedia.com/2007/07/larry-thomas-seinfeld-postal-actorsoup.html Larry Thomas, ''Seinfeld'' actor, audio interview] at MrMedia.com

revision.comment: Rescued 1 archive link; reformat 1 link. [[User:GreenC/WaybackMedic_2.1|Wayback Medic 2.1]]
revision.text:
{{good article}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Unita Blackwell | image = Unita Blackwell.jpg | caption = | birth_name = U.Z. Brown | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1933|3|18}} | birth_place = [[Lula, Mississippi|Lula]], Mississippi | residence = [[Nursing home]] on the [[Mississippi Gulf Coast]] | nationality = American | other_names = | known_for = First female African-American [[mayor]] in Mississippi, [[civil rights]] activist }}
'''Unita Zelma Blackwell''' (born March 18, 1933) is an [[American Civil Rights Movement|American civil rights]] activist who was the first [[African Americans|African American]] woman, and the tenth African American, to be elected mayor in the [[U.S. state]] of [[Mississippi]].<ref name="Birth">Blackwell 2006, p. 10.</ref> Blackwell was a project director for the [[Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee]] (SNCC) and helped organize voter drives for African Americans across Mississippi. She is also a founder of the [[US China Peoples Friendship Association]], a group dedicated to promoting cultural exchange between the [[United States]] and [[China]]. ''Barefootin{{'}}'', Blackwell's autobiography, published in 2006, charts her activism.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wcwonline.org/content/view/1585/38 |title=Wellesley Centers for Women  — Stepping Out and Moving Forward |publisher=wcwonline.org |access-date=April 27, 2008 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080311034423/http://www.wcwonline.org/content/view/1585/38 |archivedate=March 11, 2008 |df= }}</ref>
==Early life== Unita Blackwell was born on March 18, 1933, in [[Lula, Mississippi]], to [[sharecroppers]] Virda Mae and Willie Brown.<ref name="Birth"/><ref name="Wickenburg">{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/183552041/?terms=Unita%2BBlackwell|title=She Got It In Her Head To Change Things|last=Wickenburg|first=Beth|date=March 12, 1978|work=The Clarion-Ledger|accessdate=April 9, 2017|location=Mayersville, MS}}</ref><ref>Morrison 1987, p. 99.</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aaregistry.com/detail.php?id=2290 |title=The African American Registry |access-date=July 24, 2009 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://arquivo.pt/wayback/20091001134852/http://www.aaregistry.com/detail.php?id%3D2290 |archivedate=October 1, 2009 |df= }}</ref><ref name="BET">{{cite news | url=http://www.bet.com/news/national/2012/03/18/this-day-in-black-history-march-18-1933.html | title=This Day in Black History: March 18, 1933 | work=BET National News | date=March 18, 2012 | accessdate=March 3, 2015 | author=Middleton, Britt}}</ref> Blackwell's uncle gave her the name U.Z., which she kept until she was in the [[sixth grade]] when her teacher told her that she needed "a real name, not just initials". Blackwell and her teacher decided on Unita Zelma.<ref>Blackwell 2006, pp. 11, 47–48.</ref>
Blackwell and her parents lived in Lula until 1936, when she was three years old; Blackwell's father left the plantation on which he worked, and fled to [[Memphis, Tennessee]], fearing for his life after he confronted his boss about speaking to his wife.<ref>Blackwell 2006, pp. 12–13.</ref> Soon afterwards, Blackwell and her mother left the plantation to live with him.<ref name="breakup"/> Blackwell's family traveled frequently in search of work.<ref name="Haskins p.15">Haskins 1999, p. 15.</ref> On June 20, 1938, Blackwell's parents separated due to religious differences. Blackwell and her mother went to [[Helena-West Helena, Arkansas|West Helena, Arkansas]], to live with Blackwell's great aunt so that she had the opportunity to receive an education.<ref name="breakup">Blackwell 2006, p. 13.</ref> A quality education in Mississippi was not an option for Blackwell because the schools there were centered on the cultivation of crops and the plantation system.<ref name="Oral History">{{Cite web |url=https://www.usm.edu/oral-history/oral-history-collections-z#B |title=Oral History with Honorable Unita Blackwell |last=Garvey |first=Mike |website=Mississippi Oral History Program of University of Southern Mississippi |publisher=The University of Southern Mississippi Center for Oral History and Cultural Heritage |access-date=October 25, 2013}}</ref> While living in West Helena, Blackwell often visited her father in Memphis. During the summer months she would leave West Helena and live with her grandfather and grandmother in Lula, where she helped plant and harvest cotton.<ref>Blackwell 2006, pp. 13–14.</ref> Blackwell spent a majority of her early years chopping cotton in Mississippi, Arkansas, and Tennessee and peeling tomatoes in Florida.<ref name="African American History Online">{{Cite web |url=http://www.fofweb.com/activelink2.asp? |title=Blackwell, Unita |last=Carey |first=Charles W. |website=African-American Political Leaders, Revised Edition, A to Z of African Americans |publisher=Facts on File, Inc. |access-date=October 25, 2013}}</ref> She was 14 when she finished the [[eighth grade]], the final year of school at Westside, a school in West Helena for black children.<ref>Blackwell 2006, pp. 48–49.</ref> Blackwell had to quit school to earn for her family.<ref name="Haskins p.15" />
===Marriage and move=== Blackwell was 25 when she first met Jeremiah Blackwell, a cook for the [[U.S. Army Corps of Engineers]].<ref>Blackwell 2006, pp. 52–53.</ref> A few years later, they traveled to [[Clarksdale, Mississippi]], and were married by a [[justice of the peace]].<ref name="page101">Morrison 1987, p. 101.</ref>
In January 1957, Blackwell became extremely ill and was taken to the hospital in West Helena where she was pronounced dead. She was later found to be alive in her hospital room, and claims to have had a [[near-death experience]].<ref>Blackwell 2006, pp. 56–58.</ref> On July 2, 1957, the couple's only son, Jeremiah Blackwell Jr. (Jerry), was born.<ref name="page101"/><ref>Blackwell 2006, p. 55.</ref> In 1960, Jeremiah's grandmother, "Miss Vashti", died. A few months later, the Blackwells moved into the [[shotgun house]] that his grandmother had left to him, in [[Mayersville, Mississippi]], a town of nearly five hundred people.<ref name="African American History Online" /><ref name="page101"/> The Blackwell family was eventually able to build a larger brick home, but Blackwell wanted to keep the smaller house inherited from Jeremiah's grandmother.<ref name="Haskins p.15"/> After settling in Mayersville, Blackwell began to get involved in the Civil Rights Movement.<ref name="African American History Online" />
{{quote|I am grateful for this house...I kept it because it reminded me of where I came from.<small>—Unita Blackwell</small><ref name="Profiles">{{cite book|title=Contemporary Black Biography: Profiles from the International Black Community|last=Phelps|first=Shirelle|year=1998|publisher=Gale Research|location=Detroit, Michigan}}</ref>}}
==Civil rights activism==
===Voting discrimination=== Blackwell first got involved in the [[Civil Rights Movement]] in June 1964, when two activists from the [[Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee]] came to Mayersville and held meetings in the church she belonged to concerning African Americans' right to vote.<ref>Blackwell 2006, pp. 65–74.</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://library.wustl.edu/units/spec/filmandmedia/collections/hampton/eyes1/blackwell.htm |title=Unita Blackwell |publisher=Washington University Film & Media Archive |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081002214309/http://library.wustl.edu/units/spec/filmandmedia/collections/hampton/eyes1/blackwell.htm |archive-date=October 2, 2008 |dead-url=yes |access-date=June 9, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://americanradioworks.publicradio.org/features/oh_freedom/interview_blackwell.html |title=Oh Freedom Over Me: Selected Interviews, Unita Blackwell |last=Biewen |first=John |last2=Kate Cavett |year=1994 |publisher=American Public Media |access-date=December 27, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Voices of Freedom |last=Hampton |first=Henry |authorlink=Henry Hampton |author2=Steve Fayer |year=1990 |publisher=Bantam Books |location=New York, NY |isbn=0-553-05734-0}}</ref> The following week she and seven others went to the courthouse to take a voter registration test so that they could vote.<ref name="white">Blackwell 2006, pp. 3–8, 75.</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://digital.wustl.edu/cgi/t/text/text-idx?c=eop;iel=4;view=toc;idno=bla0015.0999.011 |title=Interview with Unita Blackwell |date=May 7, 1986 |publisher=Blackside, Inc. |access-date=July 24, 2009}}</ref> While they were outside the courthouse waiting to take the test, a group of white farmers from the area heard what was happening and tried to scare them off.<ref name="white"/> The group stayed there all day, but only two were able to take the test. The racism that the group experienced, Blackwell says, made that day "the turning point" of her life.<ref>Blackwell 2006, p. 7.</ref> Jeremiah and Unita lost their jobs the next day after their employer found out that they had been part of the group.<ref>Blackwell 2006, pp. 75–76.</ref> After losing her job, Blackwell recounts her family's means of survival:
{{quote|We had a garden; people would give us a pot of beans...SNCC was supposed to send us eleven dollars every two weeks. My husband worked three months of the year for the Army Corps of Engineers, then we'd buy lots of canned goods <small>—Unita Blackwell</small><ref name="Profiles"/>}}
Blackwell attempted to pass the test three times over the next few months. In early fall she took the test successfully and became a registered voter.<ref>Blackwell 2006, pp. 76–77, 103–104.</ref>
When the [[United States Commission on Civil Rights]] came to Mississippi in January 1965, Blackwell testified in front of them about her experiences with voter discrimination:<ref>Blackwell 2006, pp. 123–124.</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.usccr.gov/pubs/msdelta/ch3.htm |title=Racial and Ethnic Tensions in American Communities: Poverty, Inequality, and Discrimination—Volume VII: The Mississippi Delta Report — Chapter 3: Voting Rights and Political Representation in the Mississippi Delta |publisher=United States Commission on Civil Rights |access-date=December 29, 2009}}</ref>
{{quote|I filled it out and I had section 97 and I wrote it down and looked it over and I picked some of the words out of, you know, what I had wrote down; put that in there and turned it over. And I misspelled 'length' and I said 'Oh, my Lord.' And so then I filled out the rest of it and when I got through I handed it to her, and I said 'Well, I misspelled this, and well, I didn't date the top,' and she said 'Oh, that's all right, it's all right, it's all right.' And then she ran and got the book and [registered me]. <small>—Unita Blackwell</small><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.law.umaryland.edu/marshall/usccr/documents/cr12v94.pdf |title=Voting in Mississippi — A report of The United States Commission on Civil Rights |year=1965 |publisher=[[United States Commission on Civil Rights]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100611013934/http://www.law.umaryland.edu/marshall/usccr/documents/cr12v94.pdf |archive-date=11 June 2010 |dead-url=yes |access-date=29 December 2009}}</ref>}}
As a result of Blackwell's involvement with voter registration campaigns, she and other activists endured constant harassment.<ref name="Haskins p.16">Haskins 1999, p. 16.</ref>
===SNCC and other movements=== After meeting [[Fannie Lou Hamer]] in the summer of 1964 and hearing her experiences in the Civil Rights Movement, Blackwell decided to join the [[Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee|SNCC]].<ref>Blackwell 2006, pp. 82–83.</ref><ref>Klopfer 2005, p. 468.</ref> As a project director for the SNCC, she organized voter registration drives across Mississippi.<ref>Blackwell 2006, pp. 83–92.</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Can You Make A Difference?: A Memoir of a Life for Change |last=Schwartz |first=Robert J. |year=2002 |publisher=[[Lantern Books]] |location=New York, NY |isbn=1-59056-032-9}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.nybooks.com/articles/2009/12/17/growing-up-female/ |title=Growing Up Female |last=Schine |first=Cathleen |authorlink=Cathleen Schine |date=November 20, 2009 |publisher=[[The New York Review of Books]] |access-date=December 8, 2009}}</ref> Later that year, she became a member on the executive committee of the [[Mississippi Freedom Democratic Party]] (MFDP), which provided a party for voters that SNCC had been registering to vote.<ref name="BET"/><ref name="African American History Online" /><ref>Blackwell 2006, pp. 104–106.</ref><ref>Crawford 1993, p. 21.</ref> In late August she and 67 other elected MFDP delegates traveled to the [[1964 Democratic National Convention]] in [[Atlantic City, New Jersey]], intending to get the MFDP seated as "the only democratically constituted delegation from Mississippi."<ref>Blackwell 2006, pp. 106–117.</ref><ref name=king/> They were eventually offered two [[Plurality-at-large voting|at-large seats]] but refused that compromise; the event, particularly Hamer's nationally televised testimony before the credentialing committee, brought the party and the Mississippi civil rights movement into the public eye.<ref>Blackwell 2006, pp. 111–118.</ref><ref name=king>{{cite web|title=Mississippi Freedom Democratic Party (MFDP)|url=http://kingencyclopedia.stanford.edu/encyclopedia/encyclopedia/enc_mississippi_freedom_democratic_party/|publisher=King Encyclopedia|agency=stanford.edu|access-date=January 21, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180211160716/http://kingencyclopedia.stanford.edu/encyclopedia/encyclopedia/enc_mississippi_freedom_democratic_party/|archive-date=February 11, 2018|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
In the late 1960s Blackwell worked as a community development specialist with the [[National Council of Negro Women]]. In the 1970s, through the National Council of Negro Women, she worked on a development program for low-income housing and encouraged people across the country "to build their own homes."<ref name="African American History Online" /> During her time participating in the Civil Rights Movement, she was jailed over 70 times because of her role in civil rights protests and other actions.<ref name="Haskins p.16" />
===''Blackwell v. Issaquena County Board of Education''=== [[File:Logo SNCC.svg|thumb|100px|The SNCC pin]] The Blackwells filed a suit, ''Blackwell v. Issaquena County Board of Education'', against the [[Issaquena County, Mississippi|Issaquena County]] Board of Education on April 1, 1965, after the principal suspended over 300 black children, including Jerry, the Blackwells' son, for wearing pins that depicted a black hand and a white hand clasped with the word "SNCC" below them.<ref>Blackwell 2006, pp. 133–136.</ref> The suit covered several issues including the students' use of the "freedom pins", and asked that the Issaquena County School District desegregate their schools per the Supreme Court ruling in ''[[Brown v. Board of Education]]''.<ref>Blackwell 2006, p. 136.</ref> The United States District Court for the Southern District of Mississippi decided that the students were being disruptive with their use of the freedom pins, but that the school district had to desegregate their schools to comply with federal law, by the Fall of 1965.<ref>Blackwell 2006, pp. 136–137, 139.</ref> The case was taken to the United States Court of Appeals Fifth Circuit in July 1966, where the previous decision by the District Court was upheld.<ref>{{cite court |litigants=Blackwell v. Issaquena County Board of Education |vol=363 |reporter=F.2d |opinion=749 |pinpoint= |court=United States Court of Appeals Fifth Circuit |date=July 21, 1966 |url=http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/z?r102:S23JN2-140: |archive-url=https://archive.li/20120717233935/http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/z?r102:S23JN2-140: |dead-url=yes |archive-date=July 17, 2012 |quote=The judgment is affirmed.}}</ref> Due to the case resulting in a desegregation plan, Blackwell referred to it as "one of the very first desegregation cases in Mississippi."<ref name="Mississippi Civil Rights Project">{{Cite web |url=http://mscivilrightsproject.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=6:unita-blackwell&catid=164:person&Itemid=22 |title=Unita Blackwell |publisher=Coahoma, Mississippi Civil Rights Project |access-date=October 25, 2013}}</ref>
Blackwell's son and approximately 50 other children boycotted the school, because of its decision to not let the children wear the SNCC freedom pins.<ref>Blackwell 2006, p. 137.</ref> As a result, Blackwell and some other activists in the community decided that it was vital to school those children. She helped open [[freedom schools]] in [[Issaquena County, Mississippi|Issaquena County]] to resolve the issue.<ref>Blackwell 2006, pp. 137–139.</ref> The schools became popular and continued to teach classes every summer until 1970, when the local schools finally desegregated.<ref>Blackwell 2006, p. 139.</ref>
==Political career and later life== Blackwell has been on 16 diplomatic missions to China since 1973.<ref name="query" /> As part of her commitment to better relations between the United States and China, she served for six years as president of the US-China Peoples Friendship Association, an association dedicated to promoting cultural exchange between the United States and China.<ref name="African American History Online" /> In 1979 Blackwell was appointed to the U.S. National Commission on the [[International Year of the Child]].<ref name="Haskins p.15"/> She was elected mayor of [[Mayersville, Mississippi]] in 1976 and held this office until 2001, making her the first female African-American mayor in Mississippi.<ref>Klopfer 2005, pp. 418–19, 504.</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.ruraldevelopment.org/bdbios.html |title=Board Members |publisher=ruraldevelopment.org |access-date=April 27, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Eyes on the Prize: America's Civil Rights Years (1954–1965)|last=Williams|first=Juan|authorlink=Juan Williams|year=1987|publisher=Viking Penguin|location=New York, NY|isbn=0-670-81412-1}}</ref><ref name="TTT">{{cite news|url=http://www.thetowntalk.com/story/opinion/2015/02/28/rheta-johnson-voices-speak-space-time/24207199|title=Rheta Johnson: Voices speak through space and time|work=The Town Talk| date=February 28, 2015| agency=Gazette|accessdate=March 3, 2015|author=Johnson, Rheta|location=Bay St. Louis, Mississippi}}</ref>
As mayor, she oversaw the construction of several sets of public housing, the first time that federal housing had been built in [[Issaquena County, Mississippi|Issaquena County]].<ref name="query" /><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.usccr.gov/pubs/msdelta/ch4.htm |title=Racial and Ethnic Tensions in American Communities: Poverty, Inequality, and Discrimination—Volume VII: The Mississippi Delta Report — Chapter 4: Findings and Recommendations |publisher=[[United States Commission on Civil Rights]] |access-date=December 29, 2009}}</ref> Blackwell obtained federal grant money that provided Mayersville with police and fire protection, a public water system, paved streets, housing accommodations for the elderly and disabled, and other infrastructure.<ref name="African American History Online" /> She gained national attention by traveling across the country to promote the construction of low-income housing.<ref name="Haskins p.16"/>
Blackwell also served on the [[Democratic National Committee]] and as co-chairman of the [[Democratic Party of the State of Mississippi|Mississippi Democratic Party]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.iop.harvard.edu/Programs/Fellows-Study-Groups/Former-Fellows/Unita_Blackwell |title=Harvard University Institute of Politics  — Unita Blackwell |access-date=July 25, 2009 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100703061840/http://www.iop.harvard.edu/Programs/Fellows-Study-Groups/Former-Fellows/Unita_Blackwell |archivedate=July 3, 2010 |df= }}</ref> The Mississippi Freedom Democratic Party sent Blackwell and 67 other delegates to the 1964 Democratic National Convention in New Jersey.<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=k0Zx4at7OEUC&pg=PA66#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Showdown at the 1964 Democratic Convention: Lyndon Johnson, Mississippi and Civil Rights |last=Skipper |first=John C. |date=2012-03-16 |publisher=McFarland |isbn=9780786491315 |language=en}}</ref><ref name="Haskins p.16"/><ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QRZQK1-JQxwC&pg=PA525#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Mississippi Writers: Reflections of Childhood and Youth |last=Abbott |first=Dorothy |date=1985 |publisher=Univ. Press of Mississippi |isbn=9780878052387 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Smith |first=Vern |date=2004-08-01 |title=The Crisis |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-kIEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA34#v=onepage&q&f=false |language=en |publisher=The Crisis Publishing Company, Inc. |access-date=2018-01-21}}</ref> Their voices heard at the convention helped contribute to the passage of the [[Civil Rights Act of 1964]] and the [[Voting Rights Act of 1965]].<ref name="Haskins p.16"/> In late 1982 Blackwell went to the [[University of Massachusetts-Amherst]] and received a master's degree in [[regional planning]].<ref name="query">{{Cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/06/17/us/a-mayor-and-town-rise-jointly.html |title=A Mayor And Town Rise Jointly |last=Kilborn |first=Peter |date=June 17, 1992 |website=New York Times |access-date=April 27, 2008}}</ref> Although Blackwell did not attend high school, the National Rural Fellows Program helped her gain admittance to the University of Massachusetts by awarding her a scholarship and providing her credit based on her activism and life experience.<ref name="African American History Online" />
As part of her community development efforts, she helped found Mississippi Action for Community Education (MACE), a community-development organization in [[Greenville, Mississippi]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/z?r102%3AS23JN2-140%3A |title=Tribute to Unita Blackwell(Senate  — June 23, 1992) |publisher=Library of Congress |access-date=February 23, 2008 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://archive.li/20120717233935/http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/z?r102:S23JN2-140: |archivedate=July 17, 2012 |df= }}</ref> From 1990 to 1992, Blackwell was president of the [[National Conference of Black Mayors]].<ref>Klopfer 2005, p. 504.</ref><ref name="Sentinel">{{Cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=QCtDAAAAIBAJ&sjid=yawMAAAAIBAJ&dq=unita%20blackwell&pg=2409%2C3869714 |title=Democrat delegates look back to '68 convention |date=August 25, 1996 |work=The Daily Sentinel |access-date=March 15, 2011 |agency=Associated Press |page=16}}</ref> In 1991, she co-founded the Black Women Mayors' Conference as a corollary to the National Conference of Black Mayors and served as its first president.<ref name="African American History Online" /> Blackwell became a voice for rural housing and development, and in 1979 President [[Jimmy Carter]] invited her to an energy summit at [[Camp David]]. Blackwell was also awarded a $350,000 [[MacArthur Fellowship]] genius grant in 1992, for her part in creating the Deer River housing development among other creative solutions to housing and infrastructure problems in her state.<ref name="query" /><ref name="LA">{{Cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1992-08-02/opinion/op-5791_1_unita-blackwell |title=Unita Blackwell: MacArthur Genius Award Caps a Creative Political Life |last=[[Kay Mills (writer)|Mills, Kay]] |date=August 2, 1992 |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |access-date=January 7, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/06/16/nyregion/33-win-macarthur-awards-including-17-women.html |title=33 Win MacArthur Awards, Including 17 Women |last=Teltsch |first=Kathleen |date=June 16, 1992 |work=The New York Times |access-date=February 23, 2008}}</ref> Blackwell ran for Congress in 1993, but she was defeated by [[Bennie Thompson]] in the primary.<ref name="African American History Online" />
Blackwell, with help from JoAnne Prichard Morris, wrote an autobiography, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=VlN5AAAAMAAJ Barefootin': Life Lessons from the Road to Freedom]'', that covers her life working as a sharecropper for her parents, being elected mayor of Mayersville causing her rise from "Poverty to Power", and her actions in the Civil Rights Movement. It was published in 2006.
In January 2008 she disappeared from her hotel in [[Atlanta]] while attending commemoration ceremonies for Martin Luther King Jr., and was found later at [[Hartsfield-Jackson International Airport]].<ref name="African American History Online" /><ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/2008/01/20/Mississippi-mayor-found-safe/UPI-40071200871344 |title=Mississippi mayor found safe |date=January 20, 2008 |access-date=December 28, 2009 |publisher=UPI}}</ref> She was reported as having been in the early stages of [[dementia]] in 2008.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.wlbt.com/Global/story.asp?S=7747304 |title=Unita Blackwell Found after Brief Scare |date=January 19, 2008 |work=WLBT3 |access-date=June 8, 2008 |agency=Associated Press |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081002212619/http://www.wlbt.com/Global/story.asp?S=7747304 |archivedate=October 2, 2008 |df= }}</ref> Currently, Blackwell resides in a nursing home on Mississippi's Gulf Coast.<ref name="nursinghome">{{Cite news |url=http://www.clarionledger.com/story/news/2014/06/13/sharecropper-presidential-adviser/10511227 |title=From sharecropper to presidential adviser |last=Gates, Jimmie |date=June 13, 2014 |work=The Clarion-Ledger |access-date=February 21, 2015}}</ref>
==Honors and awards== * Named as fellow of the Institute of Politics at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at [[Harvard University]]<ref name="Mississippi Civil Rights Project" /> * Received Master's Degree from the University of Massachusetts in 1983<ref name="Mississippi Civil Rights Project" /> through the National Rural Fellows program. * Won the MacArthur Foundation Genius Grant in 1992<ref name="Mississippi Civil Rights Project" /> * Recipient of an honorary doctor of law from the University of Massachusetts in 1995<ref name="Haskins p.15" /> * The University of Massachusetts recognized Blackwell's abilities and philosophy of life-"to educate by doing and being."<ref name="Haskins p.15" /> * Recipient of the For My People Award, presented by [[Jackson State University]].<ref name="wdam">{{cite news | url=http://www.wdam.com/story/24482679/african-american-military-history-museum-celebrate-black-history-month | title=African American Military History Museum celebrate Black History month | work=WDAM | date=January 17, 2014 | accessdate=March 3, 2015 | author=Lowrey, Erin | location=Hattiesburg, Mississippi}}</ref>
===Tributes=== *Blackwell is featured in ''[[Standing on My Sisters' Shoulders]]'' a movie about the experiences of the women behind the civil rights movement in Mississippi.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://triblive.com/aande/movies/13327126-74/film-on-civil-rights-heroines-showing-feb-28-at-frick-environmental-center |title=Award-winning civil rights film screening at Frick Environmental Center |last=McMarlin |first=Shirley |access-date=2018-02-21 |language=en-US}}</ref>
==Bibliography== *{{cite book |title=Barefootin' |last=Blackwell |first=Unita |author2=Prichard Morris, JoAnne |year=2006 |publisher=[[Crown Publishers]] |location=New York City, New York |isbn=0-609-61060-0}}
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==Sources== *{{cite book |title=Women in the Civil Rights Movement: Trailblazers and Torchbearers, 1941–1965 |last=Crawford |first=Vicki |author2=Jacqueline Anne Rouse |author3=Barbara Woods |year=1993 |publisher=Indiana University Press |isbn=0-253-20832-7}} *{{cite book |title=Activists, Rebels, and Reformers: A – F|last=Engelbert |first=Phillis |author2=Diane M. Sawinski |year=2000 |publisher=U·X·L |isbn=0-7876-4848-5}} *{{cite book |title=Voices of Freedom |last=Hampton |first=Henry |authorlink=Henry Hampton |author2=Steve Fayer |year=1990 |publisher=Bantam Books |location=New York, NY |isbn=0-553-05734-0}} *{{cite book|last=Haskins|first=James|authorlink=James Haskins|title=Distinguished African American Political and Governmental Leaders|editor=Eleanor Holmes Norton|publisher=Oryx Press|location=Phoenix|year=1999|pages=16|isbn=1-57356-126-6}} *{{cite book |title=Where Rebels Roost... Mississippi Civil Rights Revisited |last=Klopfer |first=Susan |author2=Fred Klopfer |year=2005 |publisher=Lulu |isbn=1-4116-4102-7}} *{{cite book | last = Morrison | first = Minion K. C. | title = Black Political Mobilization: Leadership, Power, and Mass Behavior | publisher = SUNY Press |year=1987 | isbn = 0-88706-515-5 }} *{{cite book |title=Can You Make A Difference?: A Memoir of a Life for Change |last=Schwartz |first=Robert J. |year=2002 |publisher=[[Lantern Books]] |location=New York, NY |isbn=1-59056-032-9}} *{{cite book |title=Mississippi Black History Makers |last=Sewell |first=George A. |author2=Margaret L. Dwight |year=1984 |publisher=Univ. Press of Mississippi|isbn=1-60473-390-X}} *{{cite book |title=Eyes on the Prize: America's Civil Rights Years (1954–1965) |last=Williams |first=Juan |authorlink=Juan Williams |year=1987 |publisher=Viking Penguin |location=New York, NY |isbn=0-670-81412-1}}
==External links== * [https://snccdigital.org/people/unita-blackwell/ SNCC Digital Gateway: Unita Blackwell], Documentary website created by the SNCC Legacy Project and Duke University, telling the story of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee & grassroots organizing from the inside-out * [http://uscpfa.org/ USCPFA] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080513163932/http://www.ncbm.org/ National Conference of Black Mayors] * [[Oral history preservation|Oral history]] interview with Unita Blackwell. [https://digitallibrary.tulane.edu/islandora/object/tulane%3A54111 Part 1] | [https://digitallibrary.tulane.edu/islandora/object/tulane%3A53926 Part 2] | [https://digitallibrary.tulane.edu/islandora/object/tulane%3A53918 Part 3] | [https://digitallibrary.tulane.edu/islandora/object/tulane%3A53919 Part 4] | [https://digitallibrary.tulane.edu/islandora/object/tulane%3A53920 Part 5] [https://digitallibrary.tulane.edu/islandora/object/tulane%3Adent Southern Journey Oral History Collection] [[Tulane University]] {{African-American Civil Rights Movement}}

revision.text:
{{About|the entertainer|the single by Sasha|Wavy Gravy (instrumental)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox person |name = Wavy Gravy |birth_name = Hugh Nanton Romney |image = ACC The Accent Wavy Gravy passing out free ice cream (3377996458) (cropped).jpg |caption = Wavy Gravy in 2009 |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1936|5|15}} |birth_place = [[New York City]], U.S. |occupation = {{hlist|[[Activism|Activist]]|[[comedian|comic]]}} |spouse = {{marriage|[[Bonnie Beecher]] |1965}} |website = {{URL|http://www.wavygravy.net/}} |signature = WavyGravy.png }} '''Hugh Nanton Romney''' (born May 15, 1936), better known as '''Wavy Gravy''', is an American entertainer and [[activism|activist]] for peace, best known for his [[hippie]] appearance, personality and [[counterculture of the 1960s|countercultural]] beliefs. His [[moniker]] was given to him by [[B.B. King]] at the [[Texas International Pop Festival]] in 1969.<ref name="Dallasnews">{{cite web |via=Janis joplin.net |work=Dallas Morning News |url=http://www.janisjoplin.net/news/97/48/Texas-International-Pop-Festival-was-full-of-surprises-for-artists-fans-onlookers |title=Texas International Pop Festival was full of surprises for artists, fans, onlookers |author1=Michael E. Young |author2=Roy Appleton |date=August 30, 2009 |access-date=May 15, 2010}}</ref> "It's worked pretty well through my life," he says, "except with telephone operators – I have to say 'Gravy, first initial W.'"
Romney's [[clown]] persona resulted from his political activism. Frequently arrested at demonstrations, he decided he would be less likely to be arrested if he dressed as a clown, so he became a founding member of the Phurst Church of Phun, a secret society of comics and clowns dedicated to ending the Vietnam War through the use of political theater. "Clowns are safe," he said. Despite this, he also performs traditional clown activities such as jokes, magic tricks and entertaining children.
Wavy Gravy founded and co-founded several organizations, including [[Camp Winnarainbow]], the [[Seva Foundation]] and the [[Hog Farm]], an activist [[commune]]. He was also the official [[clown]] of the [[Grateful Dead]]<ref>{{cite web |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070401051000/http://artsedge.kennedy-center.org/explore/ady.cfm?day=18&month=3&year=2006 |title=Arts Days |archive-date=1 April 2007 |website=The Kennedy Center Arts Edge |url=http://artsedge.kennedy-center.org/explore/ady.cfm?day=18&month=3&year=2006 |accessdate=15 April 2018}}</ref> and has two radio shows on [[Sirius Satellite Radio]]'s ''[[Jam On]]'' station.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web |url=https://www.lifewire.com/sirus-satellite-radio-personalities-2844372 |author=Corey Deitz |date=June 19, 2018 |title=Sirius XM Satellite Radio Personalities |website=Lifewire |accessdate=2018-07-29}}</ref>
A documentary on Wavy Gravy's life, ''Saint Misbehavin': The Wavy Gravy Movie'', was released in late 2010 by Ripple Effect Films.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.rippleeffectfilms.com/wwwavy/index.php | title = Saint Misbehavin': The Wavy Gravy Movie | accessdate = 2011-01-11 | publisher = Ripple Effect Films |dead-url=usurped |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110208010429/http://www.rippleeffectfilms.com/wwwavy/index.php |archive-date=2011-02-08}}</ref> The film, directed by Michelle Esrick, received positive reviews.<ref>{{cite news | first = Stephen | last = Holden | title = The Hippie Serving Peace and Breakfast | date = December 7, 2010 | url = http://movies.nytimes.com/2010/12/08/movies/08saint.html?scp=1&sq=wavy%20gravy&st=cse | work = [[The New York Times]] | accessdate = 2011-01-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author=Frank Scheck |date=December 9, 2010 |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/saint-misbehavin-wavy-gravy-movie-58372?ref_=ttexrv_exrv_11 |title=Saint Misbehavin': The Wavy Gravy Movie -- Film Review |website=The Hollywood Reporter |accessdate=15 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sfgate.com/movies/article/Saint-Misbehavin-The-Wavy-Gravy-Movie-review-2454774.php |author=Peter Hartlaub |date=December 3, 2010 |title='Saint Misbehavin': The Wavy Gravy Movie' review |website=SFGATE |accessdate=15 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.villagevoice.com/2010-12-08/film/wavy-gravy-portrait-keeps-up-the-clown-s-disguise/?ref_=ttexrv_exrv_2 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130630135919/http://www.villagevoice.com/2010-12-08/film/wavy-gravy-portrait-keeps-up-the-clown-s-disguise/?ref_=ttexrv_exrv_2 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=30 June 2013 |title=???? |website=[[The Village Voice]] |accessdate=15 April 2018}}</ref>
==Early life== Romney was born in [[East Greenbush, New York]] on May 15, 1936. As a child, he took walks around the block with [[Albert Einstein]]. He attended [[Hall High School (Connecticut)|William Hall High School]] in [[West Hartford, Connecticut]]. In 1954, Romney volunteered for the military and was honorably discharged after 22 months in the [[United States Army]]. Under the [[G.I. Bill]], Romney entered [[Boston University]] Theater Department in 1957 and then attended the [[Neighborhood Playhouse]] for the Theater in [[New York City]]. In 1958, he began reading poetry regularly at [[The Gaslight Cafe]] in [[Greenwich Village]]. He eventually became the cafe's entertainment director, befriending musicians such as [[Bob Dylan]], [[Tom Paxton]], and [[Dave Van Ronk]].<ref>{{Cite Web|last=Van Laarhoven|first=Kaspar|title=The Story of The Gaslight Cafe, Where Dylan Premiered 'A Hard Rain's a-Gonna Fall'|website=Bedford+Bowery|publisher=[[New York Magazine]]|date=December 28, 2016|url=http://bedfordandbowery.com/2016/12/the-story-of-the-gaslight-cafe-where-dylan-premiered-a-hard-rains-a-gonna-fall/|access-date=August 9, 2018}}</ref>
==Career== His early career was managed by [[Lenny Bruce]] who brought Romney to California in 1962 where Romney did a live recording of ''Hugh Romney, [[Third Stream]] Humor'' as the opening act for [[Thelonious Monk]] at Club Renaissance in Los Angeles.<ref>Kelley, Robin D.G. ''Thelonious Monk: The Life and Times of an American Original'' Simon & Schuster 2009 p.320</ref>
===The Hog Farm=== The [[Hog Farm]] collective was established through a chain of events beginning with [[Ken Babbs]] hijacking the [[Merry Pranksters]]' bus, ''[[Further (bus)|Further]]'', to Mexico, which stranded the [[Merry Pranksters]] in Los Angeles. First Romney assembled a collective in [[North Hollywood]], visited by the likes of musicians such as [[Tiny Tim (musician)|Tiny Tim]] whom he managed, and [[Ravi Shankar]]. After moving to [[Sunland, Los Angeles|Sunland]], a suburb north of Los Angeles, he was evicted from his one-bedroom cabin when the landlord found out that a large group of assorted pranksters and musicians were staying there. Two hours later, a neighbor informed Romney that a nearby hog farm, owned by Claude Doty,<ref>{{cite web |last=Zekley |first=Mickey |year=1995 |url=http://www.larkcamp.com/adventures1.html |title=The Hog Farm Blues |work=The Adventures Of A Street Musician – Part One}}</ref> needed caretakers. Romney accepted the offer and worked the farm in exchange for rent. Local people, musicians, artists, and folks from other communes began staying at the mountain-top farm. In his book ''Something Good for a Change'', Gravy described this early period as a "bizarre communal experiment" where the "people began to outnumber the pigs".{{sfnp|Wavy Gravy|1992|p=229}}
Both Romney and his wife, [[Bonnie Beecher]], had jobs in Los Angeles. He worked for [[Columbia Pictures]] teaching improvisation skills to actors. Bonnie was a successful television actress, appearing in episodes of ''[[The Twilight Zone]]'', ''[[Gunsmoke]]'', ''[[Star Trek: The Original Series|Star Trek]]'', and ''[[The Fugitive (TV series)|The Fugitive]]''.
By 1966, the Hog Farm had coalesced into an entertainment organization providing light shows at the [[Shrine Exposition Hall]] in Los Angeles for music artists like the Grateful Dead, Cream, and Jimi Hendrix. Beginning in 1967, the collective began traveling across the country in converted school buses purchased with money earned as [[Extra (actor)|extras]] in [[Otto Preminger]]'s feature film ''[[Skidoo (film)|Skidoo]]'' (1968).
The Hog Farm relocated to Black Oak Ranch in northern California in the early 1990s.<ref>{{cite web |title=Black Oak Ranch History |url=http://katewolfmusicfestival.com/black-oak-ranch-history/ |website=Kate Wolf Music Festival |accessdate=January 23, 2016}}</ref>
===Woodstock Festival=== At the first [[Woodstock Festival]], Gravy and the Hog Farm collective accepted festival executive Stan Goldstein's offer to help with preparations.<ref name="farmfriend">{{cite book |author=Wavy Gravy |title=The Hog Farm and Friends |publisher=Links Press |date=1974 |pages=72–74 |isbn=9780825630149 |location=New York |oclc=947606}}</ref>
Gravy called his group the "Please Force," a reference to their non-intrusive tactics at keeping order, e.g., "Please don't do that, please do this instead". When asked by the press — who were the first to inform him that he and the rest of the Hog Farm were handling security — what kind of tools he intended to use to maintain order at the event, his response was "Cream pies and [[Soda syphon|seltzer bottles]]"<ref name="farmfriend"/> (both being traditional clown props). In Gravy's words: "They all wrote it down and I thought, 'the power of manipulating the media', ah ha!" <ref name=Yippie>{{Cite book|title=Blacklisted News: Secret Histories from Chicago, '68, to 1984 | author=New Yippie Book Collective | isbn=9780912873008 |publisher=Bleecker Publishing|date=1983}}</ref> Gravy has been the [[Master of Ceremonies]], and the only person to appear on the bill of all three Woodstock Festivals.{{Citation needed|date=September 2010}}
Throughout the festival, Gravy made several announcements from the concert stage. He later wrote in his memoir that "the reason that I got do to all those stage announcements was because of my relationship with [[Chip Monck|Chip Monk]] [sic]. Chip built the stage at Woodstock."<ref>{{Cite book |ref=harv |title=Something Good for a Change: Random Notes on Peace Thru Living |author=Wavy Gravy |date=1992 |publisher=St. Martin's Press |isbn=9780312078386 |edition=1st |location=New York |oclc=25367907}}</ref>
On the morning of the 20th Anniversary of the Woodstock Festival, he was interviewed — along with [[Ken Kesey]] — live on ''[[Good Morning America]]'' at the Bethel concert site, where he discussed his experience as the MC of the event.{{Citation needed|date=September 2010}}
Gravy's first appearance at an event in the [[Neo-Pagan]] community was at the WinterStar Symposium in 1998 with [[Paul Krassner]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://murugabooker.com/ace.html |title=Expanding The Frontiers Of Your Consideration |dead-url=usurped |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928075503/http://murugabooker.com/ace.html |archive-date=2007-09-28}}</ref>{{Failed verification|date=July 2018}} He appeared there again in 2000 with [[Phyllis Curott]], where he joined Rev. [[Ivan Stang]] in a joint ritual of the [[Church of the SubGenius]] and his Church of the Cosmic Giggle.{{Citation needed|date=September 2010}}
At the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum]]'s psychedelic tribute to the 1960s "[[I Want To Take You Higher]]",<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rockhall.com/exhibitpast/take-you-higher/ |title=The Psychedelic Era |publisher=The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070905195019/http://www.rockhall.com/exhibitpast/take-you-higher/ |archive-date=2007-09-05 }}</ref> Gravy's sleeping bag and tie-dyed false teeth were displayed. He and [[Paul Krassner]] appeared there on the last day of the exhibit on February 28, 1998.{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}}
==Ventures==
===Seva Foundation=== Gravy began [[Seva Foundation]] along with spiritual leader [[Ram Dass]] and public health expert [[Larry Brilliant|Dr. Larry Brilliant]]. Based in [[Berkeley, California]], Seva is an international health organization working to build sustainable health projects in many of the globe's most under-served communities. Gravy is famous for throwing all-star benefit concerts regularly featuring members of the [[Grateful Dead]], [[Bonnie Raitt]], [[Jackson Browne]], [[David Crosby]], [[Graham Nash]], [[Ani DiFranco]], [[Ben Harper]], [[Elvis Costello]] and many other compassionate musicians. He serves on Seva's board of directors.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.seva.org/site/PageServer?pagename=about/our_board |title=Seva's Board of Directors |publisher=Seva Foundation |website=www.seva.org |accessdate=2018-07-29}}</ref>
===Camp Winnarainbow=== Gravy is also the co-founder, with his wife, of the circus and performing arts camp [[Camp Winnarainbow]], in [[Laytonville, California]], near the Hog Farm.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.campwinnarainbow.org/ |title=California overnight summer camp for kids and teens |website=Camp Winnarainbow |accessdate=15 April 2018}}</ref> Until 2003, [[Ben & Jerry's]] produced an ice cream named "Wavy Gravy" (caramel-[[cashew]]-[[Brazil nut]] base with a chocolate hazelnut fudge swirl and roasted almonds) which helped drive a scholarship fund for underprivileged kids to attend Camp Winnarainbow.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thecelebritycafe.com/interviews/wavy_gravy.html |title=Wavy Gravy 1960's icon and activist |author=Dominick A. Miserandino |website=TheCelebrityCafe.com |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060101031505/http://thecelebritycafe.com/interviews/wavy_gravy.html |archive-date=2006-01-01 |accessdate=2018-07-29 }}</ref>
===Artist=== Gravy has also been recognized for his work as a [[collage]] artist. He held a solo exhibition throughout April 1999, at the [[Firehouse Gallery]] under the direction of its owner [[Eric Gibbons]].<ref>{{Cite news |title=On the Towns; Going Out |author= |newspaper=The New York Times |date=4 April 1999 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/04/04/nyregion/on-the-towns-going-out.html?pagewanted=4&src=pm |accessdate=24 October 2012 }}</ref> He is known to create larger works in collage for celebrities in the Bay Area of California. He began exploring collage in the early '60s even before becoming Wavy Gravy, his first works created while living above the Gaslight in Greenwich Village after being inspired by a [[Max Ernst]] collage he saw at the Bitter End when opening for [[Peter, Paul and Mary]].
=== "Tornado of Talent" === With hundreds of men being detained (women were held separately) in the "Hotel Diablo" – actually the old gymnasium at [[Cuesta College]] in [[San Luis Obispo, California]] – after arrests during the September 1981 [[Abalone Alliance]]-organized anti-nuclear protest, trespass/occupation and [[civil disobedience]] action at [[Diablo Canyon Power Plant]], Gravy organized and acted as MC for a variety show that he called the "Tornado of Talent" which featured, among other performers (and after the guards had allowed an acoustic guitar to be brought into the "jail"), [[Jackson Browne]]. Wavy arrived at the holding facility dressed in a pair of bright green coveralls. After settling into his "bunk" (a thin mattress on the gym floor) he removed the coveralls to reveal a Santa Claus suit.
=== Nobody's Business/Nobody for President === Gravy established the store Nobody's Business across the road from the Hog Farm,<ref>Brown, Jonathan. [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/still-hippy-after-all-these-years-395296.html "Still hippy after all these years"] ''Independent'' UK, October 25, 2007</ref> reminiscent of his "Nobody for President" campaign — as in: "Who's in Washington right now working to make the world a safer place? Nobody!"; "Nobody's Perfect"; "Nobody Keeps All Promises"; "Nobody Should Have That Much Power"; etc.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nobodyforpresident.org/|title=Nobody for President, 2020 [Official Pages]|website=www.nobodyforpresident.org|accessdate=15 April 2018}}</ref> The joke had previously been used in the 1932 short film ''[[Betty Boop for President]]''.
The "Nobody for President" campaign held a rally across from the [[White House]] on November 4, 1980 that included [[Yippies]] and a few [[anarchist]]s to promote the option of "none of the above" choice on the ballot. <ref>*[http://www.headcount.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Nobody-for-President.jpg PHOTO: Nobody For President, Curtis Spangler and Wavy Gravy, October 12, 1976] (photo credit: James Stark) ''HeadCount.org''</ref>After criticizing [[Jimmy Carter]], [[Ronald Reagan]] and [[John B. Anderson]], the committee offered the "perfect" candidate: Nobody. "Nobody makes apple pie better than Mom. And Nobody will love you when you're down and out," Gravy told a crowd of 50 onlookers at the rally.<ref>''The New York Times'' "Anarchists Push Cause of 'None of the above'" November 5, 1980</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wholeearth.com/issue/2061/article/271/20th.anniversary.rendezvous.-.wavy.gravy|author=Wavy Gravy|title=20th Anniversary Rendezvous - Wavy Gravy|publisher=Whole Earth Review|website=WholeEarth.com|date=Winter 1988}}</ref>
==Personal life== [[File:Wavy Gravy and Jahanara Romney.jpg|thumb|Wavy Gravy and his wife, Jahanara Romney (July 2013)]] Early on, he shared an apartment with singer-songwriter [[Tom Paxton]] in [[Greenwich Village]] for a time, and Romney was one of [[Bob Dylan]]'s earliest friends in [[New York City]]. One of Bob Dylan's girlfriends from the [[University of Minnesota]], [[Bonnie Beecher]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1502201/|title=Bonnie Beecher|website=IMDb|accessdate=15 April 2018}}</ref> now Jahanara Romney, married Gravy on May 22 1967.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:V668-CXF |title=Hugh M Romney & Bonnie Beecher, California Marriage Index, 1960-1985|url-access=registration|publisher=California Department of Health Services, Sacramento|type=Transcription of public record.|date=27 November 2014|website=Family Search|access-date=November 17, 2018}}</ref> They have a son, Jordan Romney (born in 1971 as Howdy Do-Good Gravy Tomahawk Truckstop Romney)
Romney has stated that he has no familial relationship with the [[Romney family]] of American politics, which includes [[George W. Romney|George W.]] and [[Mitt Romney]].
===Origin of name Wavy Gravy=== Two weeks after Woodstock, at the 1969 [[Texas International Pop Festival]] Romney was lying onstage, exhausted after spending hours trying to get festival-goers to put their clothes back on,<ref name="Dallasnews"/> when it was announced that [[B.B. King]] was going to play. Romney began to get up; a hand appeared on his shoulder. It was B.B. King, who asked, "Are you wavy gravy?" to which Romney replied "Yes." "It's OK; I can work around you," <ref>Interview {{who|date=July 2011}} on ''[[Late Night with Jimmy Fallon]]'', 26 May 2011.</ref> said B.B. King, and he and [[Johnny Winter]] proceeded to jam for hours after that. Romney said he considered this a mystical event, and assumed Wavy Gravy as his legal name.<ref name=bio>{{cite web|url=http://www.wavygravy.net/bio/biography.html|title=About - Wavy Gravy|website=wavygravy.net|accessdate=15 April 2018}}</ref>

;As himself * ''Woodstock'' (1970) * ''Flashing on the Sixties: A Tribal Document'' (1994) TV * ''The History of Rock 'N' Roll'', Vol. 6 (1995) (TV) * ''Timothy Leary's Last Trip'' (1997) * ''My Generation'' (2000) * ''The End of the Road'' (2001) * ''Ram Dass, Fierce Grace'' (2001) * ''Breaking the Rules'' (2006) * ''[[Battleground Earth]]'', episode "Ludacris vs. Tommy Lee" (2008) * ''[[Saint Misbehavin': The Wavy Gravy Movie]]'' (2008) * ''Electric Apricot Quest for Festeroo'' (2008) * ''Woodstock: Now & Then'' (2009)

'''William Holme Twentyman''' (31 October 1802 – 7 May 1884) was a [[silversmith]] in [[Cape Town]], who amassed a considerable fortune on [[Mauritius]] and retired at the age of 39. Whilst on Mauritius he created a sealed case for a pocket watch to be worn under water. After trials soldered lugs were incorporated and a "strong canvas" band was tied to the wrist for ease of use. Twentyman also painted the dial orange as to be more clearly seen underwater. This creation was known as the Twentyman "orange gorilla" due to its large size.
==Life== William Holme Twentyman was born in [[Liverpool]], the son of John Middleton Twentyman (a [[Cooper (profession)|cooper]] and trader) and Phoebe Holme. In 1818 he went to the Cape with his elder brother [[Lawrence Holme Twentyman]] (a [[silversmith]] and [[watchmaker]]), after they inherited money from a great uncle. The brothers arrived in Cape Town on 12 June 1818 on the ''Ann''. William was apprenticed to Lawrence as a silversmith and watchmaker, and later became a partner in Twentyman & Co, running his own shop next door to that of his brother.<ref>Dictionary of Mauritian Biography.</ref>
In 1828 he moved to Mauritius, arriving on the ''Winscales'' on 19 January 1829, where he ran a business as a watch seller and jeweler in [[Port Louis]].<ref>Dictionary of Mauritian Biography.</ref> On 2 June 1832 at the Anglican Church of Port Louis he married Celia Pinch, daughter of [[John Pinch the elder]] an architect in [[Bath, Somerset]]. During June/July 1832 he was caught up in the slave rebellion on Mauritius with his shop coming under siege.<ref>Recent Events at Mauritius, by John Jeremie, John Reddie, Published by Hatchard, 1835.</ref> By 1841 William had amassed a considerable fortune and, with his family, had returned to England, residing at 21 Avenue Road, [[Regent's Park]], London.<ref>London PO Directory, 1841</ref>
William Twentyman was elected [[Special Constable]] in 1848;<ref>Corporation of London Records Office</ref> was admitted to the Freedom of the [[Spectacle Makers' Company]] by redemption on 3 June 1861;<ref>Corporation of London Records Office: City Freedom Admission Papers for June 1861 [CLRO reference: CF1/1960].</ref> admitted to the [[Freedom of the City of London]] by redemption through the Spectacle Makers' Company on 6 June 1861;<ref>Corporation of London Records Office:City Freedom Admission Papers for June 1861 [CLRO reference: CF1/1960].</ref> was [[Sheriff of the City of London]] from 1861 to 1862;<ref>Corporation of London Records Office: Card Index to Sheriffs.</ref> and [[Justice of the Peace]] (JP). He died on Wednesday 7 May 1884, at his residence, Ravensworth, [[St. John's Wood]] Park, London, and was buried in [[Highgate Cemetery]]. William Twentyman left a personal estate of £28173-15-6d.<ref>Principal Probate Registry Indexes Of Wills, 1884.</ref>
